—My question is directed to Senator Robert Ray, representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the fact that, if a constituent, a member of the public, paid the Labor Party $20,000, then access to the Prime Minister might be sought on a one-on-one basis or a one-on-one consultation could be negotiated with a minister of choice and that person could also be recorded as sponsoring the relevant cabinet meeting—sort of naming rights for cabinet meetings; the `Alan Bond cabinet meeting'. When you sell the privilege of access to ministers for $20,000, don't you see why the people think you are arrogant and out of touch? Don't you see why 760,000 unemployed Australians become angry? Don't you see why the battlers say, `This is not the Labor Party of old'? Or did you, in fact, offer a battlers' discount and forget to include it in the brochure?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me first address what I regard as legitimate fundraising by political parties based more on tradition; that is, fundraising dinners, seminars and cocktail parties are a long-honoured tradition by both sides of politics.
—And raffles.

—And raffles and other things. What would not be acceptable to me or the Prime Minister, which was apparently suggested in the letter that went out, would be an arrangement where you got access to a minister or a Prime Minister by charging a fee, whatever the level. That is unacceptable. It is not this government's policy and it has never occurred in the history of this government. I cannot forgive the overzealous zeal of the marketers that sent that particular letter out—I cannot. But it was not accepted by either the Prime Minister or any cabinet minister—not accepted! They have been admonished for sending that particular letter out.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill asked about elitism. Those who were present in Brisbane last Friday—and none of those were—could have come to our $25-a-head dinner. We had 1,200 people come and 400 on the waiting list. It was a great night and a great speech by the Prime Minister. So don't talk to us about elitism.

When it comes to sponsorship of functions—because it wasn't sponsorship of cabinet—I just remind you of the 1994 fundraising dinner held in Sydney for Mr Fahey in which the Lexus car and Toohey's Brewery were the sponsors. Have a look at the article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 3 August 1994 to see that the Fahey Liberal Party government had a fundraiser sponsored by those particular two outfits. I cannot remember any Liberal here speaking out on this particular issue. Dead silence when it was the Fahey government.

What you need in the political process is full visibility and accountability of donations to political parties. That is the way to ensure probity. But when that legislation came before this chamber, all those opposite voted against disclosure. Every single one of them voted against disclosure of political donations. This is the same opposition that had one of its frontbenchers have FAI sponsor one of its staff members. Its leader had to step in and eliminate that. You made a mistake, you rectified it; we made a mistake, we have rectified it.

I would be happy to be able to say it was a good performance but I am quoting reference to a body of expert opinion which styles it as `mediocre'.

Let me quote from chapter 7 headed `Operations of the formal capital market'—

—I am quoting from a survey of superannuation funds from a reputable Australian consultancy to the National Investment Council. It stated:

Compared internationally, under this finding by the Australian National Investment Council, we are half as intelligent as the US and the UK in investing in this area of the market.

PARA.TAB: I am surprised that the Liberal Party should ever run on this issue. I have come off the back of consultations with the Australian business community—well over a thousand consultations in particular forums in the last 18 months—and the one thing they consistently raise wherever you go is that there is a lack of venture capital and a lack of developmental capital because the funds do not want to assess risk for small to medium sized companies in Australia in an intelligent way. Senator Kemp—Mr President, I take a point of order. Peter Cook is no genius but the—

TALK.START.PARA: —Use the correct title, Senator Kemp.
—Senator Cook is no genius. I will say it again.
—What is the point of order?

—The point of order is relevance. The question related to the fact that the real return on pension funds in Australia is the second highest of 18 Western nations. Mr Keating criticised the real rate of return. Senator Cook, could you answer that particular aspect of the question? You haven't answered it.
—I believe he has. It is a question of interpretation.

—Can I say that I am answering this question. We have heard one quote from one agency. I have referred to a body of other agencies and expert opinion deeming it mediocre. When other funds in other countries do better and they get a better return, isn't that an object lesson to Australian fund managers? Of course the obligation is to get maximum return; but a portfolio would be properly balanced if part of it had a focus on high risk, high return and if a small proportion of the funds were invested in high risk, high return investments. It would also unblock an area in the national economy, which would cause the economy to grow and create more jobs. I think that is axiomatic. It is a pity the Liberal Party does not understand commerce, business, superannuation or investment. That is a comment on the modern day Liberal Party which is totally out of touch with the real world.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Over the last two years during your stewardship of the portfolio, many serious pests and diseases have entered Australia with a potential for enormous damage to our fruit, vegetable and export industries. These pests and diseases include the western flower thrip, sweet potato white fly, spiralling white fly, black sigatoka, chalk brood in the bee industry, and now the papaya fruit fly in North Queensland. Why has this occurred? Have recent quarantine protocol changes increased these risks? Is AQIS bowing to the directions of the trade department, rather than considering the real disease risk based on scientific evidence?

—This is the same question as yesterday, but I am happy to answer it again to address some of the outlandish things that you, Senator Boswell, have been saying in the last 24 hours. I might add that you may like to consider just for one minute, Senator Boswell, in your chase for a press statement, the damage you might be doing to a crucial Queensland industry. Just a have a listen, Senator Boswell. Your crazy claim—based on what, I do not know, but please let me know if you have the evidence—is that an additional fruit fly for Queensland, and it has already got two, has come in `in passenger baggage from South-East Asia'. Let me know your basis for saying that. I actually think that it is far more likely, Senator Boswell, as I said yesterday, that it has come from the Torres Strait—that is, in Australia—and it has been there for some years. I told you that yesterday.

PARA.TAB: The fruit fly was detected in the Torres Strait in 1993 on five islands. It was eradicated on two islands in 1994 but not on the three northern islands where eradication is impracticable. Have a listen why, Senator Boswell: because of the close proximity of those islands to infestations which are endemic, Senator Boswell, in Irian Jaya and Papua New Guinea, where the fruit fly exists.

TALK.START.PARA: —And they actually walk across at low tide.

—Correct. They actually fly across, Senator. However, the Queensland Department of Primary Industries carried out suppression activities on these three islands. AQIS and the Queensland Department of Primary Industries cooperated in the eradication program. Earlier this year the fruit fly was detected again on the same two islands—obviously without your knowledge, Senator Boswell—from which it was previously eradicated, and also on two others. A major eradication program is already under way. AQIS is contributing half of the cost of $100,000.

PARA.TAB: In response to what you have been saying about downgrading, I might add, Senator Boswell, that a restructuring of AQIS and downsizing of staff is something that the coalition has been calling for for years. I am happy at another time to produce the press statements in here where your primary industry shadow minister, John Anderson, says that, but just have a listen to what has actually happened, Senator Boswell, in your part of the world.

AQIS has, in fact, been active in enhancing quarantine in the Torres Strait and northern Queensland for some years, including the introduction of survey and monitoring programs in the region and the top watch program, which has raised community awareness of quarantine issues, including fruit fly, to very high levels in the Torres Strait and northern peninsula communities. AQIS assisted inspectors on the larger islands at Bamaga on Cape York to inspect for movements of fruit fly product. AQIS has established an FM radio network across Cape York which broadcasts quarantine awareness messages as well as a weekly radio broadcast in the Torres Strait and a range of other public awareness initiatives. The principal regional airline servicing in the region, Sunstate and Flight West, issues ticket wallets with quarantine information printed on all pages.

There are 12 AQIS staff located in the Torres Strait and at Bamaga, and there are a further five located in Cairns who have responsibility under the Northern Australia quarantine strategy for quarantine issues in Far North Queensland and the Torres Strait. AQIS has also recently installed a detector dog team at Cairns airport to further improve quarantine surveillance of aircraft, including those that originate in the Torres Strait. It is public knowledge that AQIS has achieved substantial staffing reductions in recent years, Senator Boswell. I might add, as I have said this before publicly, that most of that is in the export services and in meat inspection—something that your party has, in fact, been calling for for years.

The important thing is: what happens now? As I said before, we already have Queensland fruit fly in Queensland. We already have protocols established for dealing with that for exports from Queensland. I am now initiating, in dialogue with the Queensland primary industries minister, what we will need to do to establish immediate research, if it is necessary to do this, to see whether those protocols and those treatments and fumigations that already deal with the two species of fruit fly that already exist in Queensland, Senator Boswell, are effective in terms of dealing with fruit fly. To indicate to you why this is important, Senator Boswell, and why you should be concentrating on this—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I would like to give Senator Collins an opportunity to extend his answer and I ask a supplementary question. For all the reasons it was done, everything good that AQIS did and all the protocols he set in place, why was it unsuccessful? Why has he in his two years let in all these other diseases? In the two years he has been responsible for AQIS, he has dropped the ball.

—The fruit fly is in the Torres Strait. I do not think the primary industry constituents in Australia would like this, but the way that Senator Boswell wants to deal with it is to close our borders. The most likely scenario for how the fruit fly got here is by light aircraft, by vehicle—because people go from Bamaga and come back to the mainland in vehicles—or in a yacht. With all the protection that can be introduced, Senator Boswell knows perfectly well that, without closing the borders, you cannot have such a no-risk policy—and even then it would not work.

PARA.TAB: One reason for that is that this pest is endemic in Papua New Guinea. The reason that no eradication techniques were introduced onto the three northernmost islands on the Torres Strait is that it was considered useless. The fly can be carried there environmentally and naturally across those waters. That is probably the reason. The important thing to remember is that Malaysia has this fly and Malaysia exports successfully into countries like Japan because the right treatment is applied to the fruit. That is what we will do now. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is he able to give the Senate a categorical assurance that neither the Minister for Foreign Affairs nor Australia's Ambassador to the United Nations, or their representatives, intervened to modify the Governor-General's speech to the United Nations so that the one issue of supreme importance to Australians—nuclear testing by the French and the Chinese—was omitted in the delivery?

—Strong references to French nuclear testing were included in the version of the speech that was approved by the foreign minister on behalf of the government. The references to French nuclear testing were included in the version of the speech which was issued formally in New York. It is a convention of the United Nations that the official version of the speech for the historical record is the full version of the text by the originating mission and the one that is distributed to other governments. So the full text is the official speech. There is a time limit of five minutes on all speeches for the special session—I would love to watch Gareth make a speech there. The Governor-General's speech in delivery was running over time. All the warning lights had begun towards the end of the speech.
—Why wasn't it planned better? Is that too much to ask?
—The reference to French nuclear testing was included in one of the three paragraphs that the Governor-General was not able to complete and did drop.
—Come on; with a professional speech writer that doesn't wash.

—He did complete the last paragraph, I understand, so it was not deliberate. A couple of the more crass interjections have asked why wasn't the speech better timed. All you have to do is sit up here in the galleries when we are in general session and listen to how well they time their speeches and how often they run out—even today. At every question time one of their questioners runs out of time to complete a question. This deletion would be unfortunate but for the fact that historically the written and issued text is regarded as the authoritative source. So there was no intervention by anyone.

—But it is surprising, Minister, isn't it, that if you have a strict five minutes you would already have one that lasts for about 7 1/2 minutes? Isn't it true that other speakers spoke for eight minutes and that, unfortunately as a result of this, New Zealand yet again was seen to give a much stronger response to this issue than Australia?

—I really do ask you to look at the interview on Larry King Live with President Chirac. Senator McMullan did make the point that that is not the perception; it does not fit the pattern of our opposition to these tests. Mr Hayden, as I understand, in the substantive part of his speech wanted to pay tribute to former foreign minister Evatt, which did take longer than he expected. It was also important to put the role of Australia and Dr Evatt in the formation of the United Nations 50 years ago. As I say, the authoritative text for this is the written speech; it is the historical version of it. That has been given adequate publicity. Your raising it today has reinforced it.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Treasurer. After the election, however, you introduced new taxes on building materials, you raised the Medicare levy, you raised the HECS contribution, you dismantled the l-a-w tax cuts and you increased sales taxes by as much as 46 per cent—for example, on cars. You are now obsessed with what coalition policies will be. But yesterday the Deputy Prime Minister, when asked to give a commitment not to raise taxes or introduce new taxes if re-elected, said, `Why on earth would we do that?' What is your government's tax policy? Given that you will not commit to not raising taxes or introducing new ones, which taxes will you increase and what new taxes do you intend to introduce?

—They have been caught out. The Business Review Weekly on Friday contains an article cobbled together from interviews with Mr Costello, Jeff Kennett and a few others which exposes a secret Liberal Party agenda on taxation. Out of your own mouths are you exposed! That agenda is to introduce income taxes for the states. Obviously, there is a great deal of embarrassment about this article in opposition ranks. Mr Costello trotted out a denial of what he was quoted as saying almost immediately the newspaper hit the newsstands. Now we have an aggressive attacking question by Senator Vanstone, pumping herself up with all the great indignation she can muster to attack the government on its taxation record.

PARA.TAB: Let us get a couple of things on the record about Senator Vanstone's question and about this government's position on taxation. The first thing is that what Senator Vanstone has said in her question by way of opening is just not true. What we promised to do at the last affection—
Opposition senators—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —It was the affection of the Australian people for us. What we promised to do at the last election was not to increase the overall burden of taxation and, as Senator Gareth Evans and I have said in this chamber many, many times—I do not have the figures to hand at the moment—nor have we. So that is a promise we have kept.

PARA.TAB: As far as the l-a-w one is concerned, that has been kept, and it was kept in this last budget as well by bringing forward the first taxation cut and making that earlier for all taxpayers in Australia than promised at the election and by, of course, providing in the last budget a payment to superannuation to compensate for the second income tax instalment. So we can go through all of the erroneous elements that set the platform for this question.

But let me go back to what is seen to be the issue here. Our tax policy is out in the open and clear. It is laid down in the last budget and the budget before that. We are on the record about it. What is the outcome of our tax policies? If you can compare the level of taxation in Australia under us to the level of taxation when you had the Treasury bench and Mr Howard, your now leader, was Treasurer and responsible for taxation policy, the tax burden on Australians now is less by a large margin than what it was when you were in power.

So the high taxing party of Australian politics is you, not us. We are the ones that have lowered the level of taxation in Australia. We have provided—I do not have the figure to hand—at least six cuts to income tax over the life of our period in government. So, on the record, who is the high taxing party? You, not us. The level of taxation was higher under you; it is lower under us. They are the clear messages.

The second point I make is that if you look at how Australia rates in the world, you would have reference to the OECD table of developed countries. That is our peer group of economies, all the developed countries in the world. We are the second lowest taxed economy in the OECD. We have only been displaced as the lowest by Turkey because Turkey re-evaluated its GDP upwards and thus lowered the percentage of the tax take from the overall economy. The secret tax agenda of the opposition is now out, published in the Business Review Weekly, and it is to impose a state income tax.

—On the same point of order, I withdraw nothing, Mr President.

—I said to Senator Vanstone, `What about this lie', and I asked her to address that as well. And I called her a fraud for raising a question in ignorance of it.

—I ask you to withdraw that, Senator Bolkus.

—What are your policies, sport?

—As Senator Collins said in answer to a question yesterday, of course Australia is, after Antarctica, the driest continent on earth. Our rainfall patterns are the most variable, and the amount of rainfall available for human activities and the environment is extremely small in comparison with other countries. For these reasons it is critically important that we significantly improve the management of Australia's water resources.

PARA.TAB: To improve the management of our water resources, we must increase our knowledge of our extremely complex river and riverine ecosystems. We must enhance the quality of our monitoring programs, and improve the management of our river systems and their catchments. Through the Prime Minister's 1992 environment statement, the Commonwealth government initiated a number of important programs to improve the management of Australia's water resources.

At the start of National Water Week I launched a major report entitled Water quality monitoring in Australia which was funded under the environment statement. The report by Aquatek Australia Pty Ltd compiled information on water quality monitoring in inland, estuarine, and coastal waters, and ground water in all states and territories. The report found that there are about 1,800 water quality monitoring programs in Australia and that $100 million is spent each year on these programs.

One of the important recommendations of the report was the need to interpret the wealth of data that has already been collected by environment protection agencies. On Sunday, I announced that the Commonwealth government would provide funding to assist with the evaluation of the water quality data that has already been collected and ensure the development of a national water quality monitoring system. The sum of $250,000 has been provided to ensure the interpretation of the long-term trend data on water quality. The analysis of this data from the Commonwealth and state EPAs will provide a baseline for measuring future performance, and will also feed into state-of-the-environment reporting.

The Commonwealth will provide $180,000 to establish a national water quality monitoring system, and 400 sites—100 sites from each of the four main environmental water types around the country—will be selected from the approximately 2,000 sites where monitoring is currently taking place. The EPA has established a working group of state and territory environment protection agencies to consider implementation of the other recommendations in this report.

Other Commonwealth initiatives to improve the management of our water resources include the national river health program which has been allocated $10 million to coordinate biomonitoring programs nationally and to study the environmental flow requirements of our rivers. The Coalition of Australian Governments 1994 report on water resources policy promotes more efficient use of water through pricing allocation and trading reforms. All these measures will have significant benefits for water quality in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), to a question without notice asked by Senator Panizza this day, relating to superannuation.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to Senator Cook's reply to my question on superannuation and the statement that Mr Keating made the other day when he called the superannuation fund managers `donkeys'. Senator Cook used OECD figures in response to a later question to justify his answer, but when I used OECD figures on superannuation he tried to blow them out of the water by quoting from some other source.

PARA.TAB: I will read into Hansard the real returns, as espoused by Asset Management of the Union Bank of Switzerland, to pension compared with 18 other Western countries. It showed that France led the field with 13 per cent. Australia was on 12.1 per cent—only 0.9 of one per cent behind France. Then we go down to Ireland on 11.2; the United Kingdom, 10.8; New Zealand, 10.5; United States, 9.6; Belgium, 9.5; Spain, 9.3; Canada, 8.8; Denmark, 8.8; Hong Kong, 8.6; and the 18th was Singapore on 2.3.

I believe the real reason for having superannuation in Australia, or indeed anywhere else, is to provide for real income in the retirement years of Australian people. That is the real reason. Here we have a Prime Minister who has now directed small business, which Senator Schacht is not even defending, to pay into those funds to provide for those workers who have worked in various industries for reasons that have been `forcified' by legislation. Now he seems to want to `forcify' those managers to invest in high risk and, according to Senator Cook, high return areas, but when I say the object—

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you mean by `forcify'?

—That is the way he is talking, Senator Collins. The object, as I said, of the superannuation funds is to provide secure growth for those superannuants. So superannuation funds have to be secure, of reasonable growth that is beyond inflation, so that they will be there.

PARA.TAB: Senator Cook talked about high risk bringing high returns. It normally does not work that way. I will quote some figures in high risk areas in Australia. Of every 100 companies floated in Australia—for gold mining, that is—only two per cent ever pay a dividend. That is a high risk, and even Senator Collins agrees that that is a very high risk.

In small business or in high technology—and I know these figures are common knowledge and I do not have to remind you—40 per cent of new ventures fail in two years. Those figures are around. The reason for failing is not lack of capital. If it were lack of capital in these high risk, supposedly high return areas, according to Senator Cook—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you suggesting superannuation should not go into small business?
—I would listen to what he would have to say. Of the reasons for bankruptcies amongst those enterprises, the lack of capital is only 7 1/2 per cent—
—It is still important.

—Yes, it is important, but it is a very low figure. So you cannot really say that that is what is holding Australia back—that 7 1/2 per cent. If you look at the latest gold float, which oversubscribed about 10 or 20 times, lack of capital in Australia is not a prime reason for non-success in business. There are other things, like a lack of a business ability, which accounts for 20 per cent, and economic conditions, which are brought upon by the government and which account for 30 per cent of these things failing. I have the figures; they are OECD figures, which you have been quoting, Senator Cook, when it suits you. There you are. That is the situation. I believe this minister and his Prime Minister would have us `forcify' super funds into high risk, low return, very risky return situations, where the superannuants of Australia will not have security in their old age.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the Treasurer (Mr Willis), the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) and I have made it clear—I think the whole of the government has—that we are not in the business of directing superannuation funds on their investment. Some people would like us to do that, but we are not going to do it. I made that clear as recently as yesterday in answer to a question from Senator Kernot of the Australian Democrats.

PARA.TAB: What is true is that, by and large, superannuation funds do not invest in the areas of venture capital and developmental capital. Where start-up firms need some finance to get going, superannuation funds have a higher level of risk aversion. Where small companies that have just got started have a good product in the marketplace and they want to grow and need some capital to develop their enterprise, superannuation funds are not investors to any great extent in that area of the market either. They are not just my views; these are views put to me by people in small- to medium-sized businesses all around Australia.

I am happy, as a member of the Labor government, to go to an election in which the opposition are saying that it is all hunky-dory and sweet and there is not a worry in the world, and that the superannuation funds do understand venture capital and developmental capital. If you say that, as Senator Panizza has just inferred in his remarks, no-one in small- to medium-sized business will believe you. Your credibility will be shot to ribbons and it will just be another area where the Liberal Party—the conservatives of the country—is seen as out of date and out of touch.

My first point is that we are not going to direct it. But there is a need in this area. The report that I drew the Senate's attention to in question time was a report commissioned by the National Investment Council, which is an advisory body to the federal government on investment. It sought to find out what operates in this area of the market. It commissioned a consultancy to go away and make the report. The words in the report are the words of the consultancy; they are not the words of the government. We have not written them; the consultants, after surveying the field, wrote them. What did the consultants say? I do not have the document in front of me, but I do recall the quote quite well.

They said that superannuation funds—and they named the funds—demonstrate elements of risk aversion when it comes to investment in small- to medium-sized companies. They said that, on the performance of those funds, they are 35 per cent more risk averse than similar funds in the United States and the United Kingdom—two economies with which we compare ourselves to see how well we are performing. There may be a series of behavioural reasons as to why that is the case; I can think of some that fall into that category. We have heard nothing from the opposition about trying to analyse the policy implications of this.

TALK.START.PARA: —They do not have a policy.

—They do not have a policy; that is exactly right. What we have heard is a lot of blather. One of the possible policy reasons could be that superannuation funds under this government have exploded in size and number. The reason they have is that this government has introduced superannuation so that all workers in Australia get it. You will recall that, previously, white collar workers, senior executives or public sector employees might have had superannuation. But if you did not fall into that category, you did not.

PARA.TAB: Most workers in this country regarded superannuation as a privilege of their boss or the Public Service and not for them. That was an inequity. We have remedied it, and now everyone in Australia who works for a living is entitled to superannuation cover and to look forward to a dignified retirement because of that provision.

Given the explosion in the volume and number of funds, there are a number of people, new to the task and lacking in experience, managing investment decisions in those funds. We have done a number of things to help them gain experience. But the funds still seem to be impervious to what assessment of risk is in small- to medium-sized businesses and to balancing their portfolio of investment to develop some funds in this area. The Prime Minister is concerned to point that out. It means that companies like Pacific Dunlop are bought by foreigners, not Australians, when they are put on the Stock Exchange for sale. They are bought by foreigners because they better understand the risk of these sorts of investments. Australians with the money to invest in keeping those companies under Australian ownership have been negligent in not devoting themselves to understanding that risk. That is the point of the issue. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. It is a super day and I am speaking in the debate a little later, but I want to respond specifically to a number of the points Senator Panizza made. He is not listed to speak on the matter of public importance and I think that is disappointing.
—But you are. You can talk later.

—But I do not want to cover these issues later. They specifically relate to Senator Panizza's comments about Senator Cook's answer. I will be brief. Senator Panizza said superannuation was available up till 1983.
—I raise a point of order. I said that as an aside across the chamber. I did not say it publicly.
—What?
—I do not resile from what I said. I said it across the chamber. I did not say it in my speech. That is what I am trying to get through to him.
—There is no point of order.
—Thanks very much for putting it on the public record.
—And I stand by it.

—Thank you for reaffirming that you stand by it and putting it on the public record. I want to make a very brief point about that. Until this government was elected in 1983, less than 40 per cent of working people in this country had superannuation. The vast majority of people had to depend on the traditional age pension—at the present time about $8,300 a year. People who took out superannuation were, as Senator Cook has described, people who were in the Public Service, where there was and still is a very generous scheme, with very significant contributions from government.

PARA.TAB: There was also personal private superannuation that was offered. But the difficulty was, Senator, it was prefaced—it has changed now significantly—on a scheme of tax deductibility and tax concessions. If you look at the way in which those tax concessions operate, it is generally only higher income earners who can take advantage of some of those tax concessions. In fact, what we had was a situation where, with a significant subsidy from the government—I am not saying that necessarily was wrong—only people generally on a higher income could take advantage of it. You may well have been one of those, Senator Panizza.

Until 1983, hundreds of thousands of people—probably at least a million people—who had their own personal superannuation had taken it out as a result of the tax concessions. They tended to be male. They tended to be higher income earners, they were in a public service fund or they were senior management in corporations. The poor worker, who would be earning less than $35,000 a year—in many cases much less than that—did not have access because employers often did not offer their superannuation funds to their employees. So they had to go and take personal superannuation out, if they had the disposable consumer income available to go and buy that superannuation product. Higher income earners generally have that and not lower income earners. That is the point I want to make, Senator Panizza. It is not a point I am going to repeat in my next contribution.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), to a question without notice asked by Senator Vanstone this day, relating to taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook claimed to the Senate and to the Australian community this afternoon that this government is a low taxing government. He made comparisons with the OECD and left the clear impression that the government is a low taxing government and that we should judge what it is going to do in the future by what it has done in the past. Those policies are set out in the budget papers.

PARA.TAB: Let me set the facts of the last few years before the Senate and the Australian community. Since Paul Keating has been Prime Minister, in the first full year of his reign as Prime Minister, 1992-93, the total taxes and charges by this government from the community totalled $95 billion. This year, 1995-96, the total of taxes and charges is $125 billion—a 31 per cent increase over a three-year period. Big spending, big taxing government!

In addition to this big, huge increase in taxes and charges over a three-year period, at the start of that period, the 1992-93 financial year, the debt by the Commonwealth was $30 billion. Today it is over $90 billion and, at the end of this financial year, the budget papers and government announcements indicate it will be very close to $100 billion. Not only have they taken in this huge increase in taxes and charges, but they have also borrowed another $70 billion and spent that too.

But it is worse than that. They have sold off some of the silver—Qantas, half of the Commonwealth Bank, CSL, et cetera. If we go back to the same starting point, 1992-93, at least $5 billion of the silver owned by the community has been sold off, and they have spent that too. And worse than that again, going back to the same starting point, back at the start of the 1992-93 financial year, the Commonwealth spent about 4.7 per cent of its outlays on infrastructure—that is, investments in the community. Back in Mr Hawke's day it was nearly eight per cent but, since Mr Keating has been Prime Minister, it has gone to less than five per cent. What is it this current financial year that we are over a quarter of the way through? I dare you to guess. It is minus 2.3 per cent.

So we have this big-spending, big-taxing government claiming we should look to their policies for the future by looking at what they have done in the past. I say to the Australian community, just look at what they have done in the past three years. We cannot afford to go on like this. Anyone who runs a household understands that not only can you not increase charges in the manner they have, but to borrow and spend that and to then sell off part of the farm and spend that too, and then to stop investing in infrastructure, is an absolute disgrace.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the same matter, Mr President, what Senator Gibson and, for that matter, no-one else on that side will go to is this absolute formula. On that side of the chamber they say they will never introduce new revenue measures—full stop, straight out. Secondly, they go on to assert that the budget should go into surplus without, if you like, any capital sums. Thirdly, in order to do that, it is necessary to cut government expenditure. They are the three principal tenets that they assert.

PARA.TAB: But, of course, there are one or two missing elements that they are not willing to comment on. They are not willing to comment on why their shadow ministers are running around this country promising a whole raft of increased expenditures over a whole range of programs. I am not saying that this is a concerted effort by shadow cabinet to say that they will have this amount of expenditure but, every time a problem comes up—it might be Senator Campbell today on youth suicide or Mr Tim Fischer about more money for black spot programs—right across the board this opposition says they should spend more money. At the same time they say that expenditure should be cut, but they do not identify one area in which to cut expenditure.

There are four large departments which are big spenders. Are you going to cut Social Security; are you going to cut health; are you going to cut Defence; or are you going to cut DEET? All we get is this dull, blank stare that you get from a white pointer shark. The eyes go glazy; they are not willing to identify where the cuts will be. Political cowardice takes over, and they just say, `Trust us; we will do the cuts, but we won't tell you about them in advance. Just trust us to cut.' (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement made by the President earlier today relating to question time.

SPEECH.PARA: The basic issue the President was asked to comment on today by Senator Harradine was a decision that was presumably supported by the Procedure Committee regarding question allocation being reduced for the WA Greens, the Independents and the Australian Democrats. In the case of Independent senators, it is to be reduced from one question every three days to one question every four days.

PARA.TAB: In my opinion this is a very unfair decision which undermines the role of question time. We had a process for resolving this issue. It started well but it has gone astray. I would like to raise those concerns.

The opposition raised the issue of question allocation. We accept that there is a basis for the opposition's concerns. We have attempted to engage in constructive dialogue to solve the problem and it is unfortunate that the final decision has now been made without the involvement of the Greens and the Independents. We believe that we are being gagged and that the role of question time is being undermined.

It is the prerogative of the President to set the allocation of questions. The current system has operated during the term of this parliament and for as long as I have been in this chamber. Initially, the President attempted to answer the concerns of the opposition through negotiations between all parties. This was very productive to begin with.

We agree that there is a need for a constructive approach which affirms the role of question time and also accommodates the opposition's concerns. However, what has happened is that it has degenerated into a private deal between the parties, using the Senate Standing Committee on Procedure for cover. The Greens and the Independents are not represented on this committee. We would like to have some representation. I understand that the government and the opposition are willing to allow us on to the committee, but that does not deal with the issue before us now.

The fact is that the Procedure Committee met last week and supported the decision that has been made and that was going to be enforced by the President from today. An attempt has been made to establish a principle of proportionality for question allocation. As Senator Harradine has said, no such principle has existed previously. We are also supported by the Clerk of the Senate in that assertion.

What is the purpose of question time? It is a forum for the accountability of the executive. The allocation of questions should be fair, but with regard to the purpose. The purpose is ministerial accountability. Therefore ministers and the President should be excluded from any proportional formula that might be used to ensure fairness. Just work out what will happen if, with the change being brought about for the last 16 days of this sitting, there is a change of government. The government, in the form of the coalition, will have enormous advantages in relation to dorothy dixers. The whole principle of proportionality will, instead of ensuring fairness, overrule what I believe is a higher principle of accountability of ministers. It is the opportunity that ministers have to give an account of themselves to the people via the parliament and via the questions put forward by opposition parties.

If the coalition were in government it would be favoured because of its proportional representation and that would violate the principle of accountability of the executive—to the detriment of both the government and the opposition. While it is generally held in this place that each senator should be treated equally, this is nonsensical, given the clear distinctions between government and non-government senators.

The Greens are willing to come to an alternative arrangement which accommodates the opposition's desire for a greater number of questions, but not at the expense of existing allocations to individual senators. We should work forwards and not backwards. No-one should be disadvantaged. We should work for a win-win situation. Along these lines, we suggested to the President that there should be a set allocation of 18 questions per day, removing the overall time limit, and reducing the answer time limit from four minutes to three minutes. This allocation of questions would be based on the current system and be expanded along proportional lines.

The removal of time limits is an incentive for the government to answer questions as efficiently as possible to ensure the containment of question time in the daily program, while allowing for longer answers where necessary. This allocation will better reflect question time as a forum for scrutiny of the executive. Any change to the system should obviously be for a trial period. This was the proposal that I wanted to put before the Procedure Committee, but I was unable to do that because we were not represented.

The role and processes of this place should not be compromised by party interests. Deals should not be done behind closed doors and the vital role of question time should not be diminished. The legitimate voices of the Greens and Independents should not be silenced. This should definitely not be happening in the dying days of the session before we go to an election.

I ask the President to reconsider his decision and again engage in dialogue between all parties. We would be willing to look at an interim measure to extend question time and to give the opposition further questions until the issue is resolved. In the interests of the Senate and in order to make my comments clearer, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the President's letters and our letters to the President setting out the possible alternative arrangement.
Leave granted.

Dear Mr President
I am writing in response to your letter of 7 September 1995 regarding the allocation of questions in Senate question time.
In your letter you state that:
"In principle the distribution of the call during question time should be in proportion to the numbers in the Senate of the various parties, groups and independent Senators."

The Greens (WA) believe that no such principle exists in the Senate for the allocation of questions. Odgers' Senate Practice makes no mention of such a principle and the Clerk of the Senate confirms our view.

It is widely acknowledged that question time is a forum for Parliament to scrutinise the actions of the executive government. This scrutiny has become even more important as the range and significance of decisions made by the executive has increased and many avenues of Parliamentary scrutiny have closed or diminished.
We believe the ability of all non-government Senators to scrutinise Ministerial actions must not be diluted.
We understand that this issue has arisen because of Opposition concern about their allocation in proportion to the minor parties and independents.
The Greens (WA) are willing to consider an alternative arrangement for the allocation of

questions. In doing so we recognise that a precedent, while not existing previously, will be established. As such, we are willing to consider any proposal which uses the current system as the minimum bench mark for the allocation of questions and expands from that point, not contracts.
If we are to use a system based on representation then its logical conclusion is to exclude Government Ministers and yourself from any calculation and, arguably, all Government Senators.

An initial suggestion would be to establish a question time of a set allocation per day, removing the overall time limit. The following allocation is suggested: Government 5; Coalition 10; Democrats 2; Greens (WA) and Independent Senators each guaranteed one question every three days. These figures are based on the current representation of the Senate, excluding Ministers and the President (see the attached table). The removal of the time limit is an incentive for the Government to answer questions as efficiently as possible to ensure the containment of question time in the daily program, while allowing for longer answers where necessary. This allocation better reflects question time as a forum for scrutiny of the executive. The ability of Government backbenchers to contribute to such scrutiny is preserved.

The Greens (WA) look forward to further debate on this issue. We believe that it is possible to arrive at a constructive solution, which will not disadvantage minor parties and independents, address the concerns of the Opposition and preserve question time as an effective vehicle for scrutiny of the executive.

ALLOCATION OF QUESTIONS
The purpose of this letter is to invite senators to express views on the allocation between the parties and independent senators of questions at question time.
In principle the distribution of the call during question time should be in proportion to the numbers in the Senate of the various parties, groups and independent senators.

I have continued the practice of my predecessor of giving the Australian Democrats two questions per day and sharing one question per day between the Greens (WA) and the independent senators as a practical means of applying that principle. However, a fixed number of questions for these groups, combined with a fluctuating total number of questions, particularly with the increasing use of supplementary questions over which I have no control, is producing a less proportional result, which has tended to favour the minor parties and independents. The attached figures show that the Democrats' and Independents' share of questions has increased.

I have accepted that some variation from precise proportionality is unavoidable but have also accepted that if that variation becomes excessive then some action would have to be taken to bring the distribution of questions back towards proportionality.

I suggested the following solution. The Greens (WA) share of questions would be reduced to two questions every four days and the Democrats would receive one question per day plus a second question after thirteen questions had been asked on any one day. Where this total was not reached on four consecutive days the Democrats would receive a second question on the fourth day. Using the figures for the call for the first half of 1995, these proposals would still have produced an outcome slightly favourable to the Democrats and the Greens.

At a meeting of all party whips and representatives of the Greens on Thursday 24 August 1995 it was clear that the underlying assumption—that questions should be distributed approximately in proportion to membership of the Senate—was not universally accepted. Various proposals to change question time were canvassed, for example, a fixed number of questions, for time to be added to question time to compensate for points of order or other interruptions and exclusion of ministers from the calculation of the government party's share of membership of the Senate. These matters were clearly beyond the competence of the meeting to resolve.

I had hoped that my proposal to adjust the share of questions would be accepted and that proposals for fundamental change to question time would be referred to the Procedure Committee. However I, understand that this is not generally acceptable. I have therefore returned to the established practice.
These matters will be further considered by the Procedure Committee. I invite senators to put any views in writing addressed to me.
Yours sincerely
MICHAEL BEAHAN

DISTRIBUTION OF QUESTIONS

Since becoming President I have sought to apply the principle that the distribution of the `call' during Question Time should approximate the proportion of membership of the Senate of the various parties, groups and independent Senators. I have continued the practice of my predecessor of giving the Australian Democrats two questions and sharing one question per day between the Greens (WA) and the independent senators as a practical means of applying that principle. However a fixed number of questions for these two parties combined with a fluctuating total number of questions, particularly with the increasing use of supplementary questions over which I have no control, is producing increasingly skewed outcomes. This has tended to favour the minor parties and independents.

I have accepted that some variation from precise proportionality is unavoidable but have also accepted that if that variation became excessive then some action would have to be taken to bring the distribution of questions back towards approximate equity.

The figures for the first half of this year which I obtained from the Table Office during the recess showed that the Democrats and Independents share of questions had increased compared with 1994. Thus my office approached the Australian Democrats and Greens in the last week of the recess with proposals to reduce their shares of the `call'.

The proposals were an arithmetic solution to an arithmetic problem. The Greens(WA) share of questions would be reduced to two questions every four days and the Democrats would receive one question per day plus a second question after thirteen questions had been asked on any one day. Where this total was not reached on four consecutive days the Democrats would receive a second question on the fourth day. Using the figures for the `call' for the first half of 1995 these proposals would still have produced an outcome slightly favourable to the Democrats and the Greens.

Dear Senator Colston
Thank you for your letter of 28 August 1995 concerning the formulation of Approved Occupational Clothing Guidelines under subsection 51AL(7) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936.
I have noted the Committee's views in relation to a numbering system for future instruments.

As regards the issue of the impact of the date the Guidelines were expressed to take effect (7 June 1995) being different from the date of notification in the Gazette (21 June 1995), I wish to point out that the new Guidelines were formulated to take account of concerns from employers and uniform suppliers that some aspects of the original Guidelines were difficult to comply with.

The new Guidelines contain a number of revisions that will in fact make it easier for genuine corporate uniforms or wardrobes to be admitted to the Register of Approved Occupational Clothing (`the Register') and hence gain tax deductibility. For instance, the maximum number of colours or shades that can be used in a design has been increased from four to eight; the minimum size of corporate identifiers on accessories has been reduced; and there is greater flexibility for differing uniforms where the employer maintains separate public identities for different parts of its organisation or where uniforms differ between employees for safety reasons.

I also note that while the new Guidelines state (at Clause 23) that single items of occupational clothing, other than full body garments, will not be admitted to the Register, this simply serves to clarify the effect of Clause 10 of the original Guidelines, which stated that occupational clothing `. . . must, when considered as a set, distinctively identify the wearer as a person associated, directly or indirectly, with their employer. . . '.

Single items of occupational clothing, being worn in conjunction with conventional clothing, have never been considered to pass this test and were therefore not approved under the original Guidelines. On this basis, I have been advised that the inclusion of Clause 23 in the new Guidelines will have no effect on the eligibility or otherwise of applications for admission to the Register.

There is, however, one very minor area where the new Guidelines could be seen as being stricter than the original ones. This is in relation to the definition of `stand alone' corporate identifiers. The new Guidelines state that a stand alone identifier must be permanently affixed by being, inter alia, `sewn down on all sides', while the original Guidelines stated that such identifiers must be permanently affixed by being `sewn on'.

However, I have been advised that this difference has not, in practice, adversely affected the rights of any applicant seeking admission to the Register. This is because the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority (TCFDA)—which administers the Guidelines—did not reject any applications dated between 7 June and 21 June 1995 which would have satisfied the original Guidelines but not the new ones.

Moreover, I have been advised by the Attorney-General's Department that, as a matter of legal interpretation, the Guidelines actually commenced on the day they were published in the Gazette. This is because the paragraph in the published text of the Guidelines (paragraph 3) which states that they commence on 7 June 1995, is expressed to be explanatory only, and thus is not part of the Guidelines proper.

Thus, it appears that the original Guidelines effectively continued to operate until 21 June, both from a technical legal perspective and in practice. For any applications dated and approved by the TCFDA between 7 June and 21 June on the basis of the new Guidelines but which would have failed the original Guidelines, tax deductibility has been (and will continue to be) available from the dates the applications were approved and the clothing designs entered on the Register.

On the basis of the above information, I have been advised that the difference between the date the new Guidelines were expressed to take effect and the date of notification in the Gazette has had no prejudicial impact upon the rights of, or imposed any liabilities on, any person.
I trust this information will be of assistance to your Committee.
Yours sincerely
GEORGE GEAR

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—The President has received a letter from Senator Alston proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

The threats to the integrity of super funds and the investments of millions of Australian workers constituted by the outrageous threats and behaviour of the Prime Minister and the Secretary of the ACTU.

PROCTEXT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that informal arrangements have been made to allocate specific times to each of the speakers in today's debate. With the concurrence of the Senate, I shall ask the clerks to set the clocks accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very important motion, and I hope that the Senate will treat it with the importance it deserves. It is quite extraordinary to try to understand what has motivated people like Bill Kelty to intervene in the current Coles-Myer debate. I would have thought that it is apparent to all outsiders that the institutions are responding to widespread concerns in the community, particularly in relation to related party transactions and the combination of the role of chairman and executive officer. In those circumstances, it seems to me that it is perfectly proper for the institutions to seek to bring about higher standards of corporate governance. There have been various investment management groups who have been arguing vehemently that there needs to be a change in those arrangements, so why did Mr Kelty intervene?

PARA.TAB: He did not take issue on the merits. He did not, for example, argue that related party transactions should be of no concern to shareholders, nor did he argue that the arrangements currently in place are adequate, nor did he seek to justify the concept of an executive chairman. He simply weighed in with a series of questions clearly designed to intimidate the AMP, to make it at least think twice and, preferably, to back off.

It has to be asked: whose interest was he serving? Was he hoping to set up a golden parachute for himself as his use-by date rapidly approaches, or was he hoping to again persuade some of the major corporate operators and close friends of his to kick the ALP tin in a big way with the approach of the election? He was clearly pleading the case for the incumbents on the Coles-Myer board. He was not interested in quality of management issues. He was simply protecting his mates.

Therefore, I think it is very understandable that there are many within the union movement who would view this development with great concern. Again, one asks: why is it that Bill Kelty has strayed so far from his roots? Perhaps it is because he looks at someone like the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), and he sees a bloke who has never had a real job in his life; who has been in parliament since he was 25 years of age; who in that time has had a wife and four kids to support; who has been able to not only buy a half-million dollar home in Elizabeth Bay but has had it unoccupied for some years—in other words, forgoing very substantial rental income; and who has then been able to come up with $400,000 to put on the table—

TALK.START.PARA: —What does this have to do with superannuation?
—I am just explaining. I will tell you. It is very relevant because when you put all that together—and I will just throw in the $2 million home at Woollahra—
—You have a conspiracy theory, do you?

—No, it is a very interesting proposition. Mr Kelty realises that he is in a mug's game, and he does not want to be on welfare street when the music stops. It is precisely why people like Michael Easson and Peter Sams have been so concerned for many years—because they do not believe the ACTU truly represents workers. They are in it for themselves. You only have to look at Jennie George's performances around the country in recent times. She is not out there acting in the interests of workers; she is acting for the union oligarchy and to support the ALP's return to government by hook or by crook.

PARA.TAB: That, I would have thought, is a devastating indictment. What it means is that someone like Mr Kelty is prepared to put at risk—and, indeed, to sabotage if necessary—corporate reforms which are seen to be important by institutional investors, by the financial institutions themselves, by fund managers, by those in the financial press who take an interest in these matters and, I suspect, by the community in general.

But no, what you have is someone like Bill Kelty weighing into the debate and asking a whole series of tendentious questions: `Does the AMP have a policy on corporate governance?' It is quite clear that the ACTU does not have, so why is he asking the AMP? He asks, `Who in the organisation made the decision to intervene?' Did the rank and file get asked whether Mr Kelty should be weighing in on behalf of his mega-rich mates? Of course they did not. He is doing it off his own bat. He asked, `Has the AMP consulted with its policy holders or trustees?' Again, AMP is charged with the responsibility as a shareholder for making decisions which they regard as being in their own best interests. They are a trustee for very many small investors, and they have a responsibility to ensure that the highest standards of corporate governance prevail. So why is Mr Kelty so utterly disinterested in all these propositions?

I suppose question No. 4 is the one that really gives you an indication, because he suggests that AMP should have regard to the implications for corporate blackmail. That can only be designed to intimidate the AMP, and that is precisely why the Herald-Sun this morning gave it front-page prominence. Then Mr Kelty asked, `Has any AMP employee or representative spoken to other investors and expressed views which may have a bearing on the market price?' That is absolutely nonsensical, because who could ever say what has a bearing on the market price? You never know what affects the movement of a share, other than in broad terms, and certainly, with respect to any conversation that anyone might have had with anyone else about it, it is absolutely impossible to ascribe cause and effect.

He goes on to talk about whether the analysis and justification is based on short-term or long-term market perceptions. Again, quite clearly, he is simply arguing the case of those with whom he dines in Toorak mansions and those with whom he is closely associated. He is not interested for one moment in the welfare of superannuation funds, in the welfare of financial institutions, in making sure that they measure up to the standards that people like Senator Sherry have spelt out so carefully—and I think Senator Ferguson also—in the Senate committee hearings, in relation to the proper standards that ought to be in place.

What is the point of having those standards if you can have a bullyboy in the ACTU coming in, pushing everyone aside and saying, `Don't worry. I'm standing up for my mates irrespective. I don't care what the merits of the argument are. I want to know why you're taking the opposite side'? I have no doubt that that is precisely the way the union movement operates, and it is undoubtedly with the full approval of the Prime Minister.

That is why, when one looks at his recent interventions, we can see that once again they constitute a very serious threat to the integrity of superannuation funds. He cannot have it both ways: he cannot call them donkeys and then insist that people put billions of dollars into their care. But, even more importantly, when he rabbits on about things that—what did he say; I have forgotten now—

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, that would be typical!
—It is not typical, but it has happened on this occasion. He certainly talked about the fact that fund managers ought take a broader view. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . many managers of investment funds handling super money had still not changed old-style attitudes about preferring investment in "blue chip" stocks to meeting the requirements of newer, smaller innovative companies.
As Cheryl MacNaught, from a leading firm of investment advisers and consultants, points out in the Courier-Mail, what could you expect anyone to think when they read about that. She says:

SPEECH.PARA: for. In this country the superannuation industry, workers and business are calling for some sort of bipartisan support for the government's proposition, which has been broadly accepted as being in the national interest.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the Government monitor trends and changes in the investment portfolios of superannuation funds to enable appropriate judgments and decisions to be made about the extent of diversification.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—On behalf of the President, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Service Act, I present the annual report of the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff for the year ended 30 June 1995.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

Like other senators, I have the good fortune to enjoy the services of the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff. Obviously, most of the things that we do in this chamber are the subject of pretty close to verbatim reporting by Hansard. That is something which we sometimes underestimate. The importance of that is not just for our own benefit, but as this is the national parliament the debates that take place in this chamber and in the other place, although sometimes I think to a lesser extent in the other place, are matters of national significance and will be matters of historical significance. Hansard has a very important role to play.

PARA.TAB: Hansard is just the visible face of the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff. I think it is appropriate that some attention is paid at this point in time to some of the other services that are provided by the department. I start by singling out the Sound and Vision Office, in particular Bert Gonzalez, the Director of Engineering and Projects, in the basement of Parliament House. What many people do not realise is that there is a city underneath the building.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right, and very few go down there.

—Very few people go down there, as Senator Sherry says. It is not always an easy environment in which to work. The people down there put in an enormous amount of effort. I take the opportunity to thank Bert Gonzalez and his team for some assistance they provided to me a couple of months ago in trying to find new ways in which to present the proceedings of parliament. I am very grateful for their assistance in digitising some sound grabs from a speech so that those sound grabs could be incorporated in a talking Hansard.

PARA.TAB: We need to be more innovative if we are going to make the proceedings of this chamber appealing to people outside. One of the great problems that all honourable senators would recognise is that many young Australians are immensely bored with the whole issue of politics. I think it is because we have relied on traditional methods of explaining to them what we do in this place. As I said on radio today, politics ought to be exciting; the proceedings of parliament ought to be exciting.

The things that we do here determine the future of people's lives. Young people, more so than any other group, ought to get involved in and excited by politics and ought to be excited about the prospect of getting involved in the decision making process. To do that, obviously we have to look for new ways to inform people about what happens in this place and new ways to spread the message about the decisions we make. If we can do more work in terms of innovative presentation, if we can have more talking Hansards and more audio-visual presentation of material, I think that will do something to bridge that gap.

I put on record my appreciation of Bert Gonzalez and his team. The work they did was first-class. It was done with good grace and with a spirit of helpfulness which is prevalent throughout much of the staff in Parliament House.

I move on to discuss the vexed issue of our computers. This is an area, I feel, where unfortunately some of the solutions that have been put forward have not been as innovative as they could have been. I am a member of POITAG, which for those who do not know what the acronym means is the Presiding Officers Information Technology Advisory Group. I suppose I share some of the responsibility for this. We have to get out of the mind-set that computing is merely glorified typewriting or word processing with a little bit of spreadsheet work and some E-mail. There is a lot more that can be done.

I have said this before: I would like to see the time when the computers in this place are linked in such a way that everybody had Internet access; everybody had external E-mail addresses as well as internal E-mail addresses; the technology allowed us to have on the computer screen a live feed from either chamber as well as a capacity to capture those images, sound grabs or whatever and to use them in a true multimedia sense. This is not an indulgence for senators and members. It is a fact that outside the walls of this building computing is moving on at a tremendous pace. Multimedia applications are moving on at a tremendous pace. We run the risk of being left behind.

The crazy situation is that outside this building people have incredible access to the Internet and have the capacity to receive information through Internet E-mail. In spite of having hundreds of computers installed in this building in members' and senators' offices, we do not have the capacity from our own offices to access the Internet; nor do we have the capacity to receive Internet E-mail. If we are fortunate to be on POITAG and to be part of the trial, we still have to go around to the Senate resources offices to get access to this.

It is very much the work of the Department of the Senate which has driven some of the changes in computer communications rather than the work of the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff. I think that is a shame. Hopefully that is something that will be rectified in the forthcoming year, because the national parliament ought to be at the forefront of communications if we are going to stay relevant. That is what all my comments are aimed at—making sure that the parliament stays relevant to the people and stays accessible.

If we were to say, `We're going to stick our heads in the sand,' that would be unacceptable, in the same way as it would have been unacceptable hundreds of years ago to say we would not allow Mr Hansard to make his verbatim reports of parliament. I think if Mr Hansard were here today in the Australian parliament, he would be all for multimedia presentations of parliamentary debates, because he would see it as the most effective way of letting people know what happens in their parliament and what happens in the decision making process of their country.

I would like to conclude by making some comments about Hansard itself. I note that in the report it said that Hansard wishes to discuss with senators and members the question of accuracy. Generally speaking, Hansard is fairly accurate. We do have a lot of cooperation from Hansard staff and, generally, if they have any queries, they come back to us. I do not mean this as a criticism of Hansard, but I have had one occasion this year when I said that I was not satisfied with the Hansard pink, for the simple reason that it did not accurately reflect the speech that I gave.

I think that reflects the problem of how far does Hansard go in trying to be verbatim and how far should Hansard go in trying to make us look more articulate. I think there is a certain amount of that in the process as well. I think Hansard have a very difficult task, because if they reported verbatim everything that we said, senators and members would always be complaining, saying, `I would rather you didn't say that. I'd rather you had me saying this, because this is what I meant to say.'

However, at the same time, one of the difficulties is that Hansard transcripts sometimes do not read like the speech. People who speak regularly in this place or in the other place know that a speech will read differently from the delivery and that what is a good speech does not always necessarily read well. But at the same time, to accurately—

Sometimes we say things that might not be grammatically perfect or we say things that may appear repetitive, but it is because in giving the speech it is necessary to capture a mood or a rhythm or a sense of something and the particular words are very important. SPEECH.PARA: The first report I have tabled recommends the construction of a modern purpose-built field hospital for the Australian Army at Holsworthy to replace the existing inadequate medical facilities of 1 Field Hospital at Ingleburn in Sydney's west. The proposed hospital is required to support Australian Defence Force operations during a contingency, in accordance with the defence policy of self-reliance, as outlined in the 1994 Defence White Paper.

The proposed facility will provide health care for regular Defence personnel located in the area known as the Liverpool Military Area, as well as Army Reserve personnel and visiting overseas military forces. The hospital will consist of a field component, and an Australian Support Area component which will continue to service those personnel who do not deploy when the field hospital deploys on operations. The facility is based on a 25 bed ward and a 16 bed self-care rehabilitation unit.
The estimated cost when referred to the Committee was $19.7m at December 1994 prices.

In common with the defence forces of other developed nations, the Australian Defence Force provides medical and dental treatment to serving members; this is to maintain the highest standards of medical, dental and physical fitness. Such treatment is provided both in the field and in the barracks environment and ensures that members remain fit and available for operations. Field treatment for the Australian Army is provided by field hospitals such as 1 Field Hospital in Sydney and 2 Field Hospital in Brisbane.

During the public hearing a proposal was put by the Southwestern Sydney Area Health Service that Defence should make use of facilities at the Liverpool Hospital.. However, while the Committee recognises the need for certain medical procedures to be performed at civilian hospitals the Committee agrees with the Department of Defence that operational requirements necessitate 1 Field Hospital possessing a wide range of medical capabilities. These include operating theatres, intensive care, pathology and radiology services.

During its inquiry, earlier this year, into a replacement medical centre at RAAF Richmond the Committee expressed concern at the high incidence of sporting injuries requiring treatment. While the Committee recognised the need for Service personnel to become and remain physically fit, it questioned whether this fitness was being achieved in the most efficient manner. At the Holsworthy hearing the Sectional Committee was informed by Defence that injuries resulting from either training or sporting activities were of concern to Defence and were currently being investigated.

The Committee has recommended that the Department of Defence advise it of the results of the study being undertaken of training and sporting injuries in the Australian Defence Force which require medical treatment
The second report which I have tabled recommends the construction of functional working accommodation for the Ready Reserve at Gallipoli Barracks, Enoggera, Qld at a cost of $21.3m.

In May 1991 the Minister for Defence, Senator the Hon. Robert Ray, announced the Ready Reserve Program. The Ready Reserve components were formed in the Australian Defence Force in 1992 as a means of increasing the ADF's capacity to deploy well trained personnel in shorter time scales than conventional reserves
This implementation has increased the number of infantry battalions within Enoggera from two to three, without the provision of any new facilities

The success of the Ready Reserve implementation relies on the ability of 49 Royal Queensland Regiment to be an operationally effective unit. 49 Royal Queensland Regiment occupies facilities dispersed over nine separate locations. The separate locations, lack of functionality and in some cases inadequate size, detract from unit effectiveness and the effective utilisation of accommodation in Gallipoli Barracks. This also impacts on the morale of unit members as they can see that other battalions are better accommodated than 49 RQR. The unit layout as it now exists leads to inefficiencies in control, administration and training.

Construction of the proposed facilities will redress significant shortfalls existing in accommodation of 49 Royal Queensland Regiment at Enoggera. However, should there be a change in policy in relation to the retention or the role of the Ready Reserve, the facilities would be adaptable for use by other units.

The Committee has always been concerned with energy conservation measures. Therefore, the Committee requires the Department of Defence to undertake, as soon as possible, an energy audit to assess the efficiency of the existing energy management system at Enoggera Barracks. The Committee further requires the Department of Defence to make available to it, the consultants' examination of energy consumption costs for this project.
