SPEECH.PARA: AIRPORTS BILL 1995

The Airports Bill provides for major reforms to the operation, development and regulation of Federal airports. It's a bill founded upon the significant investment made in Australia's airports in recent years.

Indeed, since 1988, the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) has greatly enhanced most of the airports it presently operates. In this period, the most notable changes have been capacity increases at Sydney's Kingsford Smith Airport, international terminal improvements at Sydney and Melbourne, new terminals for Alice Springs and Darwin, supporting work for domestic terminal improvements around Australia, and most recently, a grand new international terminal at Brisbane Airport. The FAC has completed all these works on a commercial basis, without any recourse to Budget funding.

As a result of their completion, FAC airports are better placed to meet both current demand and forecast increases in this demand. They are well set for the next phase of their operation under private leasing arrangements.
Future Operational Responsibility for Airports

With much of the infrastructure enhanced, the Government announced in `Working Nation' last year that we would develop a new regulatory regime for airports and conduct a scoping study into the possible sale of the Corporation's airports.

Following endorsement of those plans at last year's ALP National Conference, the Government decided to proceed with sales by way of 50 year leases, with options for a further 49 years. The bill requires Government approval for the issuing of these options. It also dictates that each lessee be a company set up to operate the airport, and that there be only one company assuming each lease. Where a group owns more than one airport the separate airport companies may have a common holding company.

The decision to lease the airports underlines the strategic importance of the airports managed by the FAC, and the public interest considerations associated with them. The use of long term leases means that the Commonwealth will maintain ownership of the airports and that leased airports remain Commonwealth Places. It also supports continuation of Commonwealth regulatory control of the airports.

In the Budget this year the Government announced its leasing strategy. That strategy opted for the leasing of FAC airports in two stages, with the four major airports (Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane and Perth) leased in the first phase, a phase in which Sydney will be jointly leased with the new airport at Badgerys Creek, Sydney West Airport. The latter decision reflected the outcome of market testing and overseas experience which suggested that multi-airport systems were far more successful when developed on a complementary rather than competitive basis.
The Government's intention is for the first stage to be completed by the end of 1996, with the second stage involving the remaining FAC airports taking place throughout 1997-98.

This timetable is now jeopardised by Coalition threats to excise Sydney from the first phase of the leasing process. Such threats amount to economic blackmail, pure and simple. Worse still, they are nothing short of economic lunacy on the part of the Opposition.

The leasing strategy was designed to ensure maximum bidding and price tension, and therefore return to the taxpayer, by putting all the most attractive assets on the block first. If the most attractive asset, Sydney, was withheld, cross ownership restrictions would ensure that bids would either not occur, or would be far below the real value of Perth, Melbourne and Brisbane airports.

For that reason if the present leasing strategy, a strategy recommended to the Government by the best expertise of outside consultants, recommended on the basis of feedback from potential bidders, is blocked by the Parliament, the entire leasing process will of necessity be put on hold. As a result the aspirations of Melbourne, Perth, Brisbane and Adelaide for new airport operators will be frustrated by the economic irresponsibility of the Federal Coalition. In addition, work on the upgrading of Adelaide Airport's main runway will also be delayed as funds for this project are predicated on the leasing of Sydney.

At the same time the value of Sydney Airport itself is depreciated by the Coalition proposal to make its leasing conditional on an intersecting runway configuration, a configuration involving dependent cross runway jet operations. According to Air Services Australia this would cut Sydney's capacity by up to 35% while guaranteeing the airport is operated in a manner that does not maximise safety. Again, in the interests of protecting the taxpayer and flying public, the Government cannot accept such a naked attempt to vandalise the process. Any Government who did would be grossly negligent.
Sydney West

If the Coalition persists with its attempt to stymie the leasing process, it will have to bear responsibility for the resulting impact in delaying the development of Sydney's second airport, Sydney West.

Under the Government's leasing timetable the target date for completion of the first stage of Sydney West is the end of 1999. To meet this target the Government has approved planned expenditure of nearly $1 billion on the airport and associated transport links.

The first stage of development, built to a standard to accommodate major domestic and international jet traffic, will include a 2900 metre runway, a 10 000 square metre passenger terminal, parking spaces for up to four B747s and four B737s, and international standard air traffic control, rescue and fire fighting facilities.

Under the Government's leasing strategy the FAC will retain contractual responsibility for the development of Sydney West Airport until it is leased jointly with Sydney Airport. The lessee will then be required, as a condition of the lease, to complete the first stage of Sydney West to the Government's specifications and timetable.

The leasing process provides the revenue to construct Sydney West via a special levy at Kingsford Smith Airport. Therefore any delay in the leasing of Sydney sabotages what is a critical and tight timetable for the new airport. It would certainly guarantee that Sydney West is not available in time for the Year 2000 Olympic Games. If the Opposition persists with their threat to block the legislation, then responsibility for delays and traffic chaos at the time of the 2000 Olympics will rest squarely upon John Howard and his colleagues.
The Government's Policy and Future Arrangements
Turning to the general principles underlying the leasing process, many of which are reflected in the objects clause of the bill, the key points to note are:
the airports must be majority Australian owned
the Government will seek diversity of ownership to the maximum extent possible
the Government will encourage transparency and benchmark competition between the airports
as a minimum, there will be separate ownership of Sydney (including Sydney West) from Melbourne and Brisbane airports
ownership of the airports by individual airlines and associated interests will be restricted to 5%
the Commonwealth will retain responsibility for land use, planning and building controls at the major airports
the Commonwealth will retain reserve powers to deal with demand management issues that may arise during the course of the 50 year leases.
By enforcing these principles the Government hopes to see Commonwealth ownership through the FAC replaced by strategic, well resourced private sector organisations capable of;
developing and operating the airports in accordance with best international practice
using local industry and local headquarters to promote Australia's interests in the region; and
boosting the export of aviation services throughout the world.

In seeking to give effect to these objectives, the Commonwealth has undertaken extensive consultation with a range of interested parties (including the States and Territories, local government, the airlines, the aviation industry, other airport users and potential investors). This consultation process included a market testing program in February this year and the circulation in August of a package that included drafts of the two airports bills. These processes worked well and the comments received have helped shape the final regulatory arrangements.
The Airports Bill and the Airports (Transitional) Bill provide the legislative framework for the granting of leases to airport specific companies initially owned by the Commonwealth.

The companion bill, the Airports (Transitional) Bill 1995, being presented on behalf of my colleague the Hon Kim Beazley, Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance, provides the legislative basis to facilitate the leasing of the major Federal airports. It provides for the granting of leases, the transfer of assets and FAC staff to the airport companies, and related sales matters.

The Airports Bill sets out the details of the post leasing regulatory arrangements to apply to the airports. Responsibility for the regulation of on-airport matters, which currently resides with the FAC as a self administering government authority, will remain with the Commonwealth at each `core regulated airports', as well as other airports specified in the regulations.
Core regulated airports listed in the bill are:
Sydney (KSA), Melbourne, Brisbane, Perth, Adelaide, Darwin, Hobart, Launceston, Townsville, Coolangatta, Canberra, Alice Springs and Sydney West.

In accordance with the Government preference for a general economic regulator, rather than an industry specific arrangement, responsibility for the administration of Government policies in relation to airport pricing and related post leasing matters will be administered by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC).
These new roles will not alter or interfere with the cornerstones of our aviation policy arrangements or the important roles currently performed by individual agencies including:
the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, which will have primary responsibility for air safety in Australia
Air Services Australia, which will oversee the national airways system, air traffic services and aviation rescue and fire fighting services
and the Department of Transport, who will retain responsibility for aviation security arrangements as well as aircraft noise, engine emissions and curfew policy.
Consultation
To ensure successful operation of the airports, it will be essential for airport operators to understand and respond to the needs of communities, passengers and airlines.
Indeed given their critical importance and potential impact on communities and regions, airport operators will have to be doubly sensitive to local issues, especially those involving noise.

The legislative provisions require airport operators to advise on all consultations undertaken with key stakeholders such as the States and Territories, local government bodies, airlines, and other interested parties, both during the process of developing draft master and major development plans and environment plans, and prior to such plans being released for public comment. The public comment provisions then require airport operators to advise the Minister on the public comments received, and to have due regard for these comments.
In addition, opportunities for comment and consultation now available under current price oversight arrangements will apply when this becomes the responsibility of ACCC post leasing.
A number of other provisions in the bill underline the Government's commitment to retaining effective public interest regulatory control. Provisions include the requirement that;
leases can be transferred only with Ministerial approval
the airport-operator company will have statutory authority to use the airport site as an airport
the airport leasing company will be restricted to carrying on activities related to or incidental to airport operations.

The last of these will ensure that airport operators are not distracted by non-airport activities, and that airports are not put at risk by unrelated or non-core financial activities. The provisions will, however, allow airport operators to become involved in land transport access improvements.

The leasing provisions will ensure that current leases with the FAC become subleases, including the domestic terminal leases held by the airlines, as well as leases held by other on-airport businesses. All such leases will be transferred with existing obligations and benefits intact.
Similarly, airport operators will be required to make payments in lieu of rates as the FAC currently does.
Restrictions on ownership and control of airport-operator companies

The bill requires airport-operator companies to be majority Australian owned, limiting the maximum level of foreign ownership to 49%. It backs up the `Australian' status of airport operator companies by requiring that a majority of directors be either Australian citizens, and/or residents, and that central management and control be exercised from within Australia.

In addition to the 5% limit on airline ownership the airport-operator company will also be subject to a 15% limit on cross-ownership for the major airports: Sydney and Sydney West together with Melbourne; and Sydney and Sydney West together with Brisbane.

This restriction will be further supplemented by a Ministerial power to declare a person to have `practical control' (that is, control through some arrangement or agreement but which does not breach the 15% cross-ownership limit).
Land use, planning and building controls
The Commonwealth will retain control over land use planning and building at the major airports. This will also ensure a nationally consistent approach to planning and building matters.

Under current arrangements, the FAC is responsible for land use, planning and building approvals at its airports. The FAC consults with State, Territory and local governments, the airlines and other airport users on proposed airport developments. This legislation builds on and strengthens these arrangements, particularly in relation to land use planning. This will help ensure compatible development in noise affected areas off-airport.
Under the bill, each airport-operator of a core regulated airport will be required to prepare:
an airport master plan—essentially a long term land use plan appropriate to meet the forecast demands over a 20 year planning period; and

development plans for any major projects (eg runway, terminal developments) at airports which will require environmental impact assessment (as is currently the case, where significant environmental impacts would result).

These master plans and major development plans will be subject to Ministerial approval. The bill also requires the airport-operator company to undertake a `public comment' process with master plans, major development plans and environment strategies.

The detailed arrangements will be set out in regulations to be developed in consultation with the industry and other interested parties. The Airports Bill allows the regulations to specify matters to be addressed by airport operators in developing their draft plans. This will ensure there is flexibility and scope to address emerging issues.

The Commonwealth recognises the legitimate interests of the States and Territories in planning issues relating to airports and wishes to achieve appropriate outcomes in this important area. Through the provisions in the bill and the administration of the new regulatory arrangements, the Commonwealth will pursue the orderly planning and development of airports.

There is, in particular, substantial scope to protect areas surrounding the major airports from residential and other development incompatible with the long term use of the airport. Whilst constitutionally this is a State responsibility, the Commonwealth is committed to working closely with the States, and in turn expects the States' cooperation on land use planning in the vicinity of airports. This will be fundamental to avoiding any repetition of the problems created by inappropriate State and Local Government approaches to zoning and development around some of Australia's major airports.
Environment management

The leasing process has provided the opportunity to review current processes and put in place arrangements to ensure improved environmental planning in the future. The leasing process is designed to guarantee responsible environmental behaviour by all new airport operators.
A vital new element will be the requirement to develop and implement approved environment management strategies.

The development of these strategies by airport operators will be required to exhibit due regard for the range of public comments likely to be received, (including from State, Territory and local governments, local communities, and other interested parties) and will be subject to Ministerial approval. In this respect, airport environment committees such as those already established at a number of major airports will help facilitate the process.

The airport regulatory arrangements to apply post leasing will supplement the operation of existing legislation, as well as regulations relating to the curfew, runway operations, flight paths and noise acquisition/insulation programs.
Accounts and reports of airport-operator company
Transparency of each individual airport's operations is an important regulatory requirement.
The Corporations Law provides a ready source of guidelines and requirements for financial accounting and reporting by airport operators.

However, the Government will ensure that airport operators report on an airport-by-airport basis, both to enable financial transparency, and to promote benchmark comparisons between airports. This is an area where the Corporations Law alone will not achieve adequate outcomes, because it allows consolidation of the accounts of subsidiary companies.

The Airports Bill therefore allows for regulations that force new operators to produce stand-alone financial accounts and reports for submission to the ACCC. At the same time the reporting and accounting provisions of the bill encourage the use of common terminology. The Government believes such transparency provisions will complement the general economic regulatory approach.
Pricing and Quality of Service

Consistent with the approach adopted by the Government in other industry sectors, the ACCC will be responsible for prices oversight of the major airports. Prices surveillance by the ACCC will include monitoring of price caps set by the Government at the four major airports—Sydney (KSA), Melbourne, Brisbane and Perth. The price caps, which will apply to aeronautical charges and be developed as part of the leasing negotiations, will operate for five years.
The pricing arrangements will provide flexibility for caps to be adjusted to accommodate necessary infrastructure expenditure.

As well, aeronautical-related services will be subject to monitoring at these four airports by the ACCC. This decision follows concern about the potential for the exercise of market power in the provision of those services.
At other regulated airports, aeronautical charges will be monitored by the ACCC to enable an assessment of pricing levels post leasing.
To ensure their continuing adequacy, these arrangements will be reviewed before the end of the first five year pricing period.
Future Airport Operations

The bill places a restraint on the Commonwealth not to close or vary airport leases without the consent of the lessee. An airport-lessee company may, however, choose to surrender an airport lease to the Commonwealth on mutually agreed terms.

Under the proposed airports regime, airport operators will be required to act in a manner consistent with international obligations. If necessary, specific regulations made to this effect, can cover all major airports in Australia, not only those currently operated by the FAC.

Regulations can be made under the bill to control on-airport activities including liquor, commercial trading in goods and services, vehicle movements, gambling and smoking. In the absence of regulations being made by the Commonwealth, State legislation would apply. The Commonwealth is currently discussing with the States opportunities for their involvement in these areas.
Protection of airspace
An important safeguard for the current and future operation of airports is established in the bill through provisions covering the protection of airspace.

The bill provides that a declaration of prescribed airspace can be made in the interests of safety, efficiency or regularity of air transport operations. Approvals will be required for activities which would result in objects intruding into prescribed airspace. The bill also allows regulations to be made which require a person to advise the airport operator of any proposed intrusion into prescribed airspace.
Slot allocation and demand management

The Government's preference, wherever possible, is for the industry to voluntarily and cooperatively deal with emerging pressures for access to airports. Post leasing, airport operators will have the ability to set the terms and conditions of access to their airports, subject to ACCC price oversight arrangements and other legislation.

However given the 50 year duration of the airport leases, difficulties may arise that cannot be addressed by industry alone. Therefore the Commonwealth will retain reserve powers over demand management at airports. The bill includes specific provisions on the ways in which such powers would be used. Those provisions and any potential impact on the financial viability of airport companies would be considered by the Government in exercising these powers.

Within the bill there is certainly ample provision for the airport operator, users, Airservices Australia, the Civil Aviation Safety Authority and the public to express their views on airport capacity matters prior to the introduction of such a demand management scheme.
In addition, under the bill, any proposed use of demand management powers is subject to review and disallowance by the Parliament.
Other provisions

The bill includes further provisions which establish a series of checks and balances on the Government and potential airport operators. These include the granting of injunctions by the Federal Court relating to contraventions of the legislation, prosecutions, false or misleading statements or records, review of decisions, delegation of powers and the making of regulations. In addition, most decision making powers in the bill are subject to parliamentary and administrative review.
Regulations

The legislation allows for much of the fine detail of the regulatory arrangements to be set out in regulations. This is considered appropriate in view of the changing circumstances the Airports Bill needs to address.

In developing the regulations required, the Government will maintain the successful consultative approach used to develop the arrangements proposed in this bill. This process is appropriate given the wide range of interests including the travelling public, the airline industry, airport operators, potential investors, State, Territory and local governments, and the community at large.
Our aim is to complete the necessary regulations well before the first leases are finalised.
Conclusion
Most major airports, both here and overseas, have traditionally been publicly owned and operated.

The decision to sell long term airport leases is a major policy initiative which the Government believes will further enhance the development of this vital part of Australia's transport infrastructure. The decision is founded on sound economic principles and a sales strategy designed to maximise taxpayer returns. By contrast, the Opposition's proposed amendments would be operationally and economically disastrous. They are nothing short of economic voodooism and cannot be taken seriously.

Overseas experience has demonstrated that, despite the high level of public interest in airport operations, with appropriate regulatory oversight the Government no longer needs to manage the commercial operation of airports. By ensuring continuing Government control over key functions, as this bill has, no area of public interest that can be compromised by commercial considerations.

Post leasing, the Commonwealth's former role will certainly be transformed. The new focus will be on regulatory requirements, including pricing oversight and quality of service monitoring. This is consistent with the thrust of so many micro-economic reforms the Government has undertaken.

The regulatory arrangements which I have outlined will provide a full range of public interest protections. They will maintain all existing arrangements vital to protecting the public. They represent a significant step forward, breaking new ground in ensuring the orderly development of airports.

Overseas Governments have and will continue to look closely at Australia's leasing and regulatory experience. Until recently, it has been an excellent process. Regrettably the Opposition is now seeking to delay its implementation for cynical political considerations. In the process, they are greatly inconveniencing a number of large foreign and domestic investors, many of whom have spent millions preparing their bids. We would urge the Opposition to desist and abandon their economically nonsensical approach to this leasing debate.

The Government is joined by most objective commentators in the belief that this bill achieves an appropriate balance between the need to regulate airports, and the desire to promote innovative, service orientated, world leading airport operators.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
AIRPORTS (TRANSITIONAL) BILL 1995

This bill gives effect to the government's decision to sell the long-term leases over the airports currently operated by the Federal Airports Corporation under a two-phase sales process. A separate company will be formed for the purpose of holding a lease over each airport and relevant FAC staff will be transferred to the new company. In the case of Sydney and Sydney West, the airport companies will have to be purchased by the same holding company.

The bill will provide a sound legislative basis to facilitate the leasehold sale of the major federal airports. The bill provides for: the transfer of airport land and associated assets from the FAC to the Commonwealth; the granting of leases over the airports and transfer of associated assets to individual airport companies; and the orderly treatment of the FAC's debts during the sales process. It also provides for airport staff currently employed by the FAC to transfer to the airport companies.

The companion bill, the Airports Bill 1995, establishes the regulatory framework to apply to the airports following their leasing. The regulatory provisions contained in the Airports Bill are necessary to ensure that airport users and the general community receive the maximum benefit from the improvements in the delivery of airport services under the leasing process.

The provision of airport infrastructure requires a large amount of capital and, for this reason, airports have traditionally been considered the responsibility of government. However, Australian capital markets are now sufficiently sophisticated to support the development of infrastructure such as airports. Given that public interest considerations can be protected through the regulatory framework of the Airports Bill, the need for continued Commonwealth investment in airports is no longer compelling.

In addition, through the involvement of superannuation and investment managers, the airports' leasing will provide an excellent opportunity for the funds of Australian men and women to be productively employed in the provision of national infrastructure. This is to the benefit of all Australians.

The decision to lease the airports rather than sell them under freehold title was motivated by the Government's desire to retain some control over the land on which the airports are located. The length of time for which these leases will be granted will ensure that sales proceeds are roughly equivalent to a sale under freehold title.

The lease of the airports is expected to produce a significant net offset to outlays, with the majority of proceeds expected to be received in the 1996-97 financial year. The bill provides for a number of financial transactions necessary to facilitate and account for the leasing process and to allow for the orderly disposal of the FAC's assets. It is expected that these transactions will be Budget neutral. As has previously been the practice, the government is not able to reveal details of estimated proceeds from leasing the airports as this would in all likelihood influence the outcome of the process and would probably see a reduction in proceeds.

The bill now before the House contains a number of measures designed to facilitate the leasing of the federal airports. Under the bill, the land and associated assets currently held by the FAC will be transferred to the Commonwealth. Once the airport land and associated assets have been revested in the Commonwealth, the bill provides for the Commonwealth to grant a lease over the land at a particular airport to a company referred to as an airport lessee company.

Under the proposed airport regulatory regime, these companies must have the status of constitutional corporations incorporated under Corporations Law. The bill enables the government to adopt a flexible leasing process involving either selling airport companies which already hold leases over the airports or granting airport leases to the airport companies following their sale. In either case, upon the granting of an airport lease, the FAC's contractual rights and obligations at each airport, as well as its liabilities, will be transferred to the relevant airport lessee company.

It is extremely important to the government that the jobs and entitlements of FAC staff are protected under the airport leasing process. The airports are therefore to be leased either with staff in place or with staff transferring to the relevant airport company immediately after leasing. Existing awards, enterprise agreements and contracts of employment will transmit to the airport lessee companies, which will ensure that airport staff retain key terms and conditions of employment as well as entitlements to accrued benefits post transfer. Following the transfer of staff, the terms and conditions of their employment, as contained in awards, enterprise agreements and contracts of employment, will be varied only according to the terms of those agreements.

The FAC Head Office will continue to oversee the management of the remaining federal airports prior to their leasing. Consideration will also be given to developing opportunities for head office involvement in airport activities, including the possible operation of airports to be leased in the second phase of the leasing process.

In accordance with the government's stance regarding payment of stamp duty in asset sales, the sale of shares in airport lessee companies or the sale of leases over the airports are to be subject to state and territory taxes and stamp duties. This will ensure that state and territory governments receive duties to which they are entitled on sales transactions which take place in their state or territory.

The bill does, however, contain some exemptions from state and territory taxes and stamp duties. These exemptions apply only to the those transactions required to structure an airport company for sale with an airport lease and associated assets in place. In this instance, the full value of the airport company will still be subject to state and territory taxes and stamp duties through the sale of shares in the company by the Commonwealth.

From a tax perspective, the government is concerned to ensure that purchasers of airport leases and existing lessees under the FAC are not disadvantaged because of the government's choice of sales mechanism. Put another way, in terms of tax, the government is seeking, where appropriate, to treat the sale as if it was a sale by the FAC in the private market place. I refer the honourable members to the explanatory memorandum for details.

The bill now before the House contains provisions to permit the FAC to discharge its Commonwealth debt and to allow for the corporation's non-Commonwealth debts to be dealt with in an orderly manner during the leasing process. The provisions contained within the bill, coupled with the existing provisions in the FAC's statute, give the Government the flexibility to deal, in due course, with the corporation's debts in the most appropriate manner. The government can assure the honourable members that the interests of holders of the FAC's bonds will be taken into account in dealing with the FAC's debts during the sales process. The bill also facilitates the transactions necessary to ensure that the approach adopted for dealing with those debts is properly recorded in the Commonwealth's accounts.

The airports to be disposed of in the second phase of the leasing process present specific regional and administrative issues which will need to be addressed prior to their lease. For example, the airports of Canberra, Darwin and Townsville are jointly operated by the FAC and the Department of Defence. As such, new operating arrangements will need to be developed with Defence before the civil facilities at these airports can be leased.

Although a number of the airports to be leased in the second phase have been unprofitable in the past, many of them are expected to become commercially viable under private ownership through cost reductions and improved revenues. For the remaining few that may prove to be commercially non-viable, the government will examine options for securing their future, taking into account the specific financial characteristics of each airport, as well as regional interests and sensitivities.

This bill seeks to provide a sound legislative basis for the leasehold sale of the federal airports and, in conjunction with the companion Airports Bill, is a key element in assisting the government to achieve its leasing objectives. The leasing of these airports represents another step forward in the government's continuing micro-economic reform agenda. The leasing framework will promote improved efficiency in the provision of airport services through the introduction of private sector disciplines, as well as ensuring that the government receives a fair return from divesting itself of a function in which its involvement is no longer essential. I commend this bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: FAMILY LAW REFORM BILL 1994 [NO. 2]FAMILY LAW REFORM (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 23 October on motions by Senators Faulkner and Crowley:
That these bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to proceed with my remarks on the Family Law Reform Bill 1992 (No. 2) and the Family Law Reform (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1995. I spoke last evening for a short time. I am pleased to have the opportunity to do so, Mr Acting Deputy President, while you are occupying the chair—having been the distinguished chairman of the committee which reported to the parliament in November 1992, which is the report being responded to by the government with these bills.

PARA.TAB: I spoke last evening of my support and pleasure that the government had moved to remove the word custody from the bill in dealing with children. Also I did not mention last night, I do not think, but I equally approve of the change to the use of the word access. It is a word many of us became familiar with over a long period of time. It describes the right to enter and pass over a piece of land without hindrance. It also means access to one's children, as we have used it. The changes proposed will, over a period of time, bring more meaning to the act on what we are really intending.

Last evening I referred to the Child Support Agency and the formula which still needs to be addressed—and my disappointment that the government has shelved that—and the question of custody and access. I wanted to refer to the other issue that is very strong in the community and that relates to the position of grandparents to children who are the subject of a marriage which has failed.

For the most part grandparents are included in the ongoing arrangements, and it works to the benefit of the children. But in far too many cases we found in evidence before the committee—evidence that I think all of us receive in our electorate offices—that grandparents too frequently are cut off from the grandchildren that they have known in a way that indicates that it is being done for some reason other than in the best interests of the children.

Any children who have grandparents living would benefit from a good relationship with those grandparents. I could speak for the rest of the time available to me about why that is a benefit—the relationship that can develop between children and grandparents and the heritage of the family that can be passed on. In so many ways the relationship can help cover and deal with the trauma of the parents having divorced.

It is my view and, I think, the view of the committee that, in fact, the act provided for the role of grandparents to be recognised. But one cannot deny that all too frequently grandparents were excluded. One reason for this is the cost involved in bringing a matter before the court. Many grandparents would not have had the resources to enable them to do so. The way legal aid operates, it is most unlikely that grandparents would have qualified for legal aid.

One solution to that problem is that judges ask the question: what about grandparents? In granting the divorce, if there are children of the marriage, a judge is always doing so being satisfied that proper arrangements have been made for the children of the marriage. It seems open to a judge to say to the parties before him, `Are there any grandparents still living?' If there are, he is entitled to say, `What arrangements do you have to make sure that these children still have an ongoing relationship with their grandparents?' Perhaps in time when that happens, it will be much easier for grandparents to be included. Without spending more time on that issue, I welcome the addition of grandparents in the amendments that the government puts forward in this act, because if it helps to make it work better, then that is very worthwhile.

In the little time remaining to me, I want to comment on matters raised by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee on the absolutely extraordinary proposition which has been included in the bill before the Senate tonight on the location of children. The rest of it, I approve. We all know of the difficulties of locating children in many instances and the difficulties of putting things right.

But at the end of the relevant section, which I think is 67P(1), I find, and the legal and constitutional affairs committee found, a penalty of imprisonment for two years for a register found to have intentionally or recklessly disclosed certain information. If it was done intentionally, he should be fired on the spot. So that would not be a real problem as far as I am concerned. But the concept of imprisonment in these circumstances does not seem to have been explained adequately in the act itself.

The legal and constitutional affairs committee found it to be an unacceptable penalty. They raise some real questions to which the government must, in the committee stage of the bill, answer if they wish to get any support for this proposition. I am not suggesting it is not a serious issue; but I do challenge that.

I also share the concerns of the legal and constitutional affairs committee on the question of it being 21 days under a magistrate's suspension of a contact order for appeal. That is outrageous. I can imagine the way that would be used by a number of people who manipulate and interfere with contact with children. Three days, as the committee suggests, is plenty for that. I urge the government most strongly to reconsider its proposition of 21 days. I can see an order taken out every 21 days in some cases—and you have to remember that that sort of thing does occur.

There are still significant issues to be dealt with. But this bill goes a long way towards improving the act and I am glad that the government has responded to the committee's report as it has. We will support it, even if some of the proposals we are not happy with are not dealt with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, it is quite interesting to see you sitting in the chair tonight, seeing that you were chairman of this committee. You will probably agree with some of the statements I will make, but I should never ask somebody sitting in the chair to agree with somebody in a debate—because you are very impartial.

PARA.TAB: It would be an understatement to say though that the Family Law Reform Bill 1994 (No. 2) and the Family Law Reform (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1995 have been a long time in the making. The cruelty of the delay is that many thousands of people have set such store in the passage of these bills that every week the bills have been dropped down the Senate agenda, those people have become further disillusioned with the parliamentary process and even more disenchanted with the politicians.

In politics one always hopes to be remembered for some outstanding achievement. When I first started my quest for a family law committee to review the Family Law Act, I could have been forgiven for thinking I was achieving something worthwhile. Several years down the track, I believe that all I have achieved is a cruel hoax on the thousands of people who believed that changes to the Family Law Act would make their lives whole again.

Of course, in reality the hundreds of hours and the millions of words that have been written about this legislation and these changes are simply not reflected in what amounts to some paltry changes to the family law. As a non-lawyer, it seemed ludicrous to me that one parent could deny the other access to their children—that one parent could so tie up the other in legal wrangles that they sent them broke or crippled them emotionally. As a farmer, it seemed absurd that a property in one family for generations could be rendered worthless and unworkable because a family law judge insisted that it be sold or split to satisfy the legal requirements of a property settlement to someone who might only have had a very brief involvement with the farm.

The family law act committee, as it is now known, was established with the highest of ideals and the noblest of intentions. The committee worked hard, processed mountains of evidence and digested, contemplated and determined a list of 120 recommendations, of which the overwhelming majority had the support of every political party. We could have been forgiven for thinking that that was the end of the matter, that the government would report, that the bills would be drawn up and the debate would soon follow.

While I always cautioned people that the process would take a couple of years, I was certainly not prepared for the three years it would take from the time the report was tabled until it was debated in this chamber. It has taken a most circuitous route—from the Family Law Council so they could wash out a few recommendations; then to the government draftsman to fiddle with it; then with a few false starts and a few more sanitised washings from one legal body or another until the legislation we have before us today. While all this sanitising and study has gone on, the divorce rate in Australia has continued to climb; families have remained under increasing emotional trauma; and many separated couples have felt compelled to take their own lives and sometimes that of their spouses and children.

Prior to the report being tabled, over 733,000 divorces were granted under the 1976 family law bill. Since the report was tabled, another 196,580 divorces have been processed. Children involved in the divorce process now number in their millions, with nearly 800,000 since 1984. One in four Australian children is now born to an unmarried mother.

Recent statistics tell us that the Australian divorce rate is now at its highest. We used to have a failure rate of one in three marriages; today, it is four in every 10. About 70 per cent of all people who marry between the ages of 15 and 19 divorce within 10 years, and almost every male married in his teens is divorced within 20 years—frightening statistics. As a society we are failing our families and as legislators we are not responding to the needs of the community. There is much in this legislation we should acknowledge, but I cannot help but think there is so much more we ought to be doing.

It is impossible in the time allowed to argue each amendment, but there are some I wish to highlight and reflect upon. In passing, it is perhaps encouraging to note that, in the general outline in the explanatory memorandum to the bill, it suggests the bill:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . makes amendments to the Family Law Act 1975 to commence the implementation of the Government's response to the Joint Select Committee Report.

This bill focuses largely on mediation and dispute resolution and also establishes a new approach to dealing with children. If one believes in the notion that all things are achievable through negotiation, then family law should be no different.

PARA.TAB: The Family Court tells us that the number of contested divorces is quite small by comparison with the overall divorce statistic. Fifty-nine per cent of all divorces involve children and, last year alone, there were over 16,000 orders sought for custody or guardianship. While we can encourage mediation in preference to litigation, the reality is that if one does not wish to negotiate and mediate then there is no legal requirement to do so.

The government has provided additional funding for mediation services. In 1994 the Family Court Counselling Service saw over 77,000 people and 1,500 interview interventions involving family violence. The annual report of the Family Court advises that the demand for counselling is steadily increasing, and that is good. But the fact remains that divorce is now more common than it was in 1975 when the Family Law Act first came into being. It is debatable that the system is any less traumatic. We still have as many angry, disenchanted people in the community, wanting and expecting us as politicians to do something. The longer the process of reform drags on, the increasingly lower credibility we all engender in the community.

I might add to the list that the least respected people in the community are the family law judges themselves. The Family Court was set up to be a user friendly court, a legal process whereby people could come and understand and be understood. So the remarks made by the Chief Justice of the Family Court a few weeks ago on 20 September 1995 do no service to the court, to the judges or to the chief justice himself. In speaking at the second annual conference of the Family Court of Australia, Chief Justice Nicholson said:

SPEECH.PARA: There is a constant and persistent view pursued by people who are often discontented litigants, sometimes obviously dysfunctional, that the Court is in some sense designed by anti-family groups to destroy the institution of the family in society.

That is as offensive as it is judgmental. I might also add that he describes these groups as `anti-family'. Might I suggest that his remarks in support of same sex couples being recognised as a family and his claim that opposition to this view is `hysterical' and `suggestive of an increasingly authoritarian and repressive society' are as anti-family as one might possibly be. I believe the Family Court was set up to take the mumbo jumbo out of the law and make it understandable and fair to all. He went on to say in his speech this delightful quote:

PARA.TAB: An unfortunate concomitant of this approach is that some people and some politicians with limited knowledge of the issues involved, tend to latch on to such dysfunctional persons for apparent political gain.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not really appreciate that. I do not think it is befitting of the person who made the comment. What an outrageous and totally inappropriate comment for a man in charge of family law courts of this country to make. The arrogance of that statement defies comment.

PARA.TAB: I would only add that this same man wrote to me when I was attempting to establish a parliamentary inquiry into family law suggesting that it was not the place of politicians and the parliament to delve into such complex issues as family law—his implicit suggestion being that we were not competent to do so. I do not think that is quite right either, because we had some very good people on our secretariat whom I think had a good, qualified chance of making this act better.

I can only conclude that if this arrogance and total lack of understanding of common human values is indicative of the Family Court, then it is little wonder we have so much trouble with the law and it is of some surprise to me that we do not have even more. I can only hope that his inadequacies are compensated for by others more understanding of the real world and more in touch with modern families and the traumas that those people face.

In this same speech, Chief Justice Nicholson suggests that anyone espousing fathers' rights are irrational and not worth trying to talk to. I have had considerable dealings with fathers trying to get access orders to see their children upheld and I am constantly frustrated by the inexplicable lack of enforcement of orders. It was something that the family law committee heard time and time again. It was also referred to in several places in the committee's report. To now have the head of the Family Court dismiss these claims, suggesting they provide `little opportunity for rational discourse', indicates to me that the anger and discontent amongst lone parent groups about Justice Nicholson are well placed.

The parliamentary committee on family law is about to bring down its report on the administration of the Family Court, so I believe it is inappropriate for me to make any further comment about the actual operation of the court. However, very relevant to this bill before us now is the attitude of the judiciary. Justice Nicholson's remarks at the family law conference reflect the difficulties inherent in the system as the family law committee saw them when contemplating the act itself, so are pertinent to the bill we are debating here today.

In summary then, might I recap on the work of the family law committee and say that we deliberated long and hard on the Family Law Act and produced a document with 120 recommendations. The Family Law Council saw fit to accept only 79, or 66 per cent, of these recommendations. They disagreed with 17, qualified a further 16 and provided alternatives to another six. I reluctantly have to accept that the Family Law Council is probably more qualified than any group of parliamentarians. However, as elected representatives of the people, I believe we must listen to and reflect the views and opinions of those who seek our advice and intervention.

I believe the family law committee report—as, indeed, its subsequent report on child support—reflected community views and generally attempted to make better a system that is flawed, involving an issue that cannot be dealt with dispassionately. I am not persuaded of this current government's commitment to family law reform. I am in no doubt that the recent weekend comments by the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) of a new commitment to a change in family law procedures will not hold much water with the many thousands of people who have dealings with the court; nor will they hold water with the literally dozens of people who write to me complaining of lack of access to the Attorney-General and lack of any appeals procedure to air their grievances.

If you ask any member of parliament what is the major issue for people who come through the doors of their offices in the electorates, I think they would say it is family law and the problems that people have with access, custody, parenting or visiting rights—or whatever you like to call them—in the new suggested bill. I believe this government has shown a consistent pattern of resistance to change in family law. This legislation is not much better than tinkering at the edges.

The government's similar lack of response to changes in child support shows me and those involved in family law a government too intent on keeping the status quo. The current system has failed and this bill will not do nearly as much as is required to make the Family Law Act better able to act on behalf of the people in the community who have the sadness and worry of marriages breaking up. It does not happen always of their own volition, but because two people cannot get on.

I am very pleased with the evidence presented to the committee that night because it was so forceful that the committee accepted it and made recommendations almost in total accord with what the Grandparent Action Group of Western Australia were putting forward. The process has been very successful and it augurs well for the democratic processes in this country.

The bill that we have is not accepting each and every recommendation of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues. It is, as I said, accepting most of them. Nobody can say that the government is acting by knee-jerk reaction to the report. The gestation period has been a long one. The fact that it is happening, though, has not stopped the public debate.

One of the previous speakers—I think it was Senator Reid—yesterday referred to an article that appeared in the Sunday Telegraph on 1 October, a major spread entitled `Self service or blind justice?' It is three full pages together with another article in between. That is one of many articles—many of them misguided—that appear about the Family Court and the Family Law Act and how, as is said in one of the articles in the paper I have just mentioned, the Family Court fails to live up to the dream. Perhaps it was an impossible dream, because when any relationship breaks down, irrespective of how mature the people are who are involved in that breakdown, there will be some hurt, there probably will be some bitterness, and there sometimes is some anger and indeed some violence. I want to spend just a moment in addressing articles such as the one on divorce that I have mentioned. The third page of the article has a photograph of the Chief Justice of the Family Court of Australia, Mr Alastair Nicholson. It talks about the Chief Justice having a high public profile and not being a person who shirks from controversy or from asking for more money to build up the empire that perhaps is now the Family Court of Australia. It certainly is growing, and it continues to grow. Indeed, the more it grows, it seems, the more demands are placed on it.

Sooner or later, that growth is going to have to stop. The money has to come from somewhere, and it has to be raised in taxes. It might be better now if Mr Chief Justice Nicholson concentrated his efforts on the management of his court, which is now a very large court, rather than playing the role that people like myself are elected to play—being politicians. SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, I was publicly attacked in unfortunate personal terms by a Government Minister and by a senior member of the ruling Labour—
spelt incorrectly—

party for having the temerity to suggest that some re-examination was needed of the policy of the Australian Government in relation to its policy of incarcerating people, and by people I mean families who arrive in Australia by boat without visas.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the great things that supports North Queensland, and in particular the potential for North Queensland to be a centre of excellence—and not just for Australia and the near Pacific—is research in marine science, and AIMS, of course, is a principal part of that.

PARA.TAB: It is appropriate to recognise the work of AIMS because that work will have very long-term ramifications, not just for the protection of the environment but also potentially for the export of services. I should explain what I mean by that. The environment that we have on the Great Barrier Reef is unique in its scope. It is by far the largest living organism—I think that is one of the phrases that is used—in the world. But it is also a wonderful place in which to replicate a situation which is found in similar environments in the near Pacific. I refer to Papua New Guinea and the South Pacific.

AIMS is a world-class research facility that has the potential to export knowledge. As the near Pacific becomes more and more developed and the pressures on the environment increase in neighbouring countries, it will become necessary for those people to come to us and say, `You have the expertise. Tell us how we can protect our environment.' That is important for these nations in protecting fishing resources, coral reefs and marine ecosystems as a whole. All of that work will be valuable to them one day.

It will either be work for which they will be happy to pay or it will be expertise which we may choose to provide to them on an aid basis. That can only strengthen our position within the region. The work of AIMS should be considered in the broader context. I have always believed that there is enormous potential in North Queensland for regional development based on the export of services and expertise.

To be honest, in certain parts of North Queensland we are never going to have large amounts of industry because of the geographical limitations that cities such as Cairns face. But North Queensland has certain advantages which cannot be replicated elsewhere in Australia. That is why the work of AIMS is important and why I believe that the government needs to have a long-term strategy to maximise the benefits of that research.

The aid budget for this current year runs at something in the vicinity of $459 million to the near Pacific. When one considers that a large chunk of aid is over training, or is assistance in terms of managing the environment or particular problems that those countries have, AIMS could be a major source of assistance to that region. Instead of sending cash, we would have the opportunity to send expertise. I think honourable senators would well know this phrase: if you give somebody a fish you feed them for a day, but if you teach to fish you feed for life.

When we consider the very fragile marine ecosystem and the pressures on that marine ecosystem—particularly in terms of long-line fishing and the loss of fish populations through destruction of spawning grounds and so on—we see that we have a lot to offer. We can play a part in improving the lot of people in the near Pacific.

For those reasons I believe that AIMS is very much underestimated. I take this opportunity to compliment those who work at AIMS and to bring to the attention of the Senate this first-class international research centre.
