TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak tonight on the legislation in my state of Western Australia which is referred to as the first wave of industrial relations legislation enacted by the Court Liberal government. In doing so, I refer to the Workplace Agreement Act, the Minimum Conditions of Employment Act and the Industrial Relations Act. There has been a lack of critical examination of the first wave of changes in Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: I will attempt to try to rectify that in coming weeks by providing some detailed experience of Western Australian workers under that legislation. I think it is important for this parliament to examine that experience because of the endorsement by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, of the first wave of IR legislation in Western Australia, his acceptance of the principles enunciated in that legislation and his comments that his federal legislation would be likely to pursue those same principles. When you compare the rhetoric with the reality of what is happening to Western Australian workers it is very informative.

I want to refer to a workplace agreement that is in force between Linfoot Cleaning Services and a number of its cleaners who work at TAFE colleges in Western Australia. Those workers were previously under the Contract Cleaners (Ministry of Education) Award 1990, but as part of the government's drive for privatisation the contract was let to Linfoot Cleaning Services. As I understand it, they now employ some 60 to 80 cleaners under individual contracts, which I will be referring to tonight. The number of jobs have been severely reduced as a result of privatisation.

I want to turn to the detail of the working conditions that now apply to those workers. The central issue I want to refer to is that the contracts classify all employees as casual even if they work up to 38 hours per week 52 weeks of the year. The Minimum Conditions of Employment Act provides that the only conditions that are applicable to casual workers employed under workplace agreements and defined as casual are the minimum wage rates and two days unpaid bereavement leave. They are not entitled to any other conditions laid down in the much vaunted Minimum Conditions of Employment Act.

Employees who previously were employed full- or part-time are now defined as casual and have lost all the standard employment conditions such as paid sick leave, annual leave, compassionate leave and access to unpaid maternity leave. By merely classifying them as casuals, the major conditions that the Court government has held out as being protected by the Minimum Conditions of Employment Act do not apply. What we are seeing in Western Australia is a whole range of full-time and part-time permanent employees being classified as casuals to ensure that they do not gain the protections of the Minimum Conditions of Employment Act.

This particular agreement provides for an ordinary hourly rate of $11.10 per hour. That compares with the old award rate for a casual of $12.42 and for a full-time cleaner of $10.35 per hour. While at first glance this differential may seem inconsequential, their take-home pays are significantly affected under the workplace agreement by provisions which restrict or eliminate other award payments. These provisions reduce the actual additional payment and the circumstances in which it will be paid.

The workplace agreement increases ordinary shift hours from eight per day on five days of the week to 12 per day on any day of the week. Workers' hours are to be arranged to suit the needs of the employer. In addition, the workplace agreement restricts penalty rates to only those hours between 10 p.m. and 4.30 a.m. All other hours of the day are considered ordinary time. Under the award, penalty rates were payable between 6 p.m. and 6 a.m.

Significantly longer `ordinary' and longer shifts all but eliminate penalty and overtime rates and significantly reduce workers' take-home pay. It is interesting that Linfoot has been able to roster its work force to avoid any penalty payments at all under this particular workplace agreement. Penalty rates are significantly reduced under the workplace agreement—and I will refer to that shortly. For low income earners such as cleaners, penalty rates have traditionally made up a significant part of their incomes and take-home pay. Under the award, the hourly rate on a Saturday for an adult was $15.53 and for a casual it was $18.63. For a person employed under the workplace agreement at Linfoot the rate is $13.90. I have done some wage comparisons and use these as examples only.

A worker who I will call Ruby works Monday to Friday from 4.30 a.m. to 7.30 a.m. at one of the larger TAFE colleges. As a casual employee under the award she earned $200.35 per week. After signing the workplace agreement her wages reduced to $166.50 per week, representing a 17 per cent reduction in her income.

Example two is that of a married couple who I will call Bob and Ingrid. They also work the early shift but are required to work from Wednesday to Sunday. Bob was a long-term, part-time employee earning $208.81 per week under the award. Ingrid was paid casual award rates which amounted on average to $250.62 per week. Under the workplace agreement both of them earn only $199.50 per week each, representing an eight per cent drop in Bob's income and a nearly 24 per cent drop in Ingrid's income. While Bob's weekly loss is smaller he has also lost all the standard employment benefits such as access to paid sick leave and paid annual leave which applied under his previous employment contract.

Overtime payments under the award are required after eight hours work. The rate is generally time and half for the first two hours followed by double time thereafter. Higher rates are applicable on public holidays. Under the workplace agreement, overtime payments are not a requirement until more than 12 hours are worked in any one day. There is no overtime rate—it is paid at the same rate applying generally under the workplace agreement.

The standard provision for paid public holidays for full-time and part-time employees is eliminated under the workplace agreement. While the award requires penalty payments for work on public holidays, under the workplace agreement public holidays are paid at ordinary time. Award allowances for such matters as toilet cleaning, meals during overtime, distant location, travel and so on are excluded completely from the workplace agreement. Allowances that were paid to workers had ranged from as little as $4 per week to $20 per week or more. They are all eliminated under the workplace agreement.

The workplace agreement further provides that wage rates are fixed for the duration of the seven-month agreement. There is no provision for review at the expiry of the agreement. The workplace agreement provides that it will continue to operate until it is replaced by a new agreement. Wage rates are fixed for as long as this may occur. There are no CPI adjustments and no productivity adjustments.

There is a range of other provisions such as termination, occupational health and safety, payment of wages and dispute resolution provisions which are all clearly inferior to those provided by the previous award and by private awards that apply in the area. The workplace agreement has been registered with the Workplace Agreements Commissioner but obviously access to that is restricted under the legislation. I am unable to ascertain just how many of the workers are on this workplace agreement because of the extreme secrecy provisions provided by the legislation. The Liquor, Hospitality and Miscellaneous Workers Union is currently seeking an interim federal award to try to override the workplace agreement and protect the working conditions of those employees.

That is one example of what is happening to workers in Western Australia under the first wave of industrial relations legislation that John Howard and the coalition have endorsed. It is clear that the claims that workers are protected from exploitation have not been realised. The experience of workers is sign or resign. Their conditions are downgraded by their lack of bargaining power.

Workers are placed in the position of negotiating with their employer a contract similar to that which used to occur before conciliation and arbitration legislation was introduced into this country at the beginning of this century. We have turned the clock back 100 years. In the coming weeks I will provide the Senate with further information on a range of industries and detail what is happening on the ground to Western Australian workers—real people who are suffering under the Liberals' industrial relations policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting to note that Senator Chris Evans chose to bring up the topic of Western Australia today. Of course, it was his valiant leader who endorsed a strike designed to cripple a state. I could go on about this at great length, however that is not the reason I rise tonight. I merely note in passing it is typical of the behaviour that we have seen in recent months from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

PARA.TAB: I wish to address the fact that the Prime Minister of this country indulged over the weekend and at the end of last week in a most unbalanced, irrational attack on the superannuation funds. Honourable senators present will know that many of us have heard criticisms of the superannuation system, and Senator Spindler and I have shared many of those criticisms.

But it is thoroughly and utterly reprehensible for the leader of this nation to indulge in the sport of slurring people by calling them names and pretending that this is some sort of pretence to intelligence. If one is going to talk about people quaffing red wine, I note that that was a practice indulged in by members of the government about half an hour ago in their party room. I do not know if that qualifies them as donkeys, but certainly I do not think the Prime Minister is entitled to launch into the sort of attack he made on superannuation fund managers such as those at AMP without being subject to a bit of scrutiny as to why he made those comments.

It is worthy of note that the event which precipitated Mr Keating's thoroughly irrational claims was the fact that the fund managers had finally had enough of the `leadership' that was being received by Coles Myer under the regime of Mr Solomon Lew. It is no secret that Mr Lew, Mr Kelty, who was not on the board, and Mr Fox, who is on the board, are all friends of Mr Keating. There is no reason to explain this intemperate attack other than the fact that the Prime Minister did not like the fact that the superannuation fund managers required a bit of financial and business propriety from the people who were running Coles Myer.

Senator Spindler has been a frequent critic of business propriety in some of the major board companies in this country. He would accept the fact that the proper things not only must be done but also must be seen to be done. In Coles Myer there could be no doubt that there were real concerns about the standard of corporate governance in that company. What Mr Keating was saying when he abused the fund managers was this: the fund managers were donkeys because they would no longer allow Mr Solomon Lew to run the company in the fashion in which he had.

Let us not forget that the Yannon transaction, which is one of the key issues in this whole saga, is alleged to have cost the shareholders of Coles Myer $18 million. So the Prime Minister is really saying that the superannuation fund managers whose responsibility it is to look after the financial interests of those superannuation fund members should turn a blind eye to possibly $18 million of rorting from the profit line of that company. That is the most absurd and ridiculous statement that I could possibly imagine a Prime Minister making, but that is behind what he has done and that is thoroughly reprehensible.

Worse still, the Prime Minister, having realised he overstepped the mark, sent his troops in here and today we heard honourable senators from the government side saying that the Prime Minister was merely seeking to commence a debate about the superannuation industry and the future of the superannuation industry in this country. That is like saying Lizzie Borden was merely interested in doing people's nails or something.

It is a ridiculous statement. The Prime Minister was thoroughly irrational in the comments he made. If this is the future for superannuation under the government, people should recognise that the Prime Minister would prefer fund managers to indulge his political favourites rather than expect good corporate management from the people who are entrusted with shareholders' funds. That is what Labor means by saying, `Trust us with your superannuation future.' All that a blind eye from the superannuation fund managers could have resulted in was a lower return to investors.

This is not about protecting the working class. This is not about protecting people's retirement nest egg. It is about protecting the vested interests of those who are close to the Prime Minister. I think it is a disgusting attack the Prime Minister has made. I believe he should be hauled over the coals for it. Let nobody in Australia be mistaken that the Prime Minister no longer has the interests of the people of Australia at heart; his interests are merely those of his privileged and powerful friends.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address the appalling situation in Sri Lanka and to call on the Australian government to reject a one-sided interpretation of the violence in that country. It is an unfortunate fact that the news reaching the global community is dependent on the respective resources of the Sri Lankan government on the one hand and the Tamil community on the other. As a result, we have seen and heard a lot about the desperate efforts of the so-called Tamil liberation tigers to fight for freedom and self-determination of the Tamil community and the casualties caused by these forays, but we have heard very little about the atrocities committed by the government forces.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats deplore violence no matter who the perpetrators are. However, we also acknowledge that under the United Nations charter it is not only nations but peoples who are entitled to self-determination. It is important for us to be reminded of that today on this 50th anniversary of the United Nations. It is in consequence of these provisions that the Australian Democrats call on the United Nations to intervene in the tragic conflict in Sri Lanka and to assist in bringing about a solution which gives the Tamil community the degree of autonomy which is their right under the United Nations charter.

As a first step, we are requesting the Australian government to intercede with the Sri Lankan government to stop its efforts to bring about a military solution, which is causing heavy casualties among the civilian population, and to lift its blockade to enable civilians to obtain medical supplies, food and other essential services. Most importantly, the Australian Democrats call on the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans, to make a concerted and determined effort to get peace negotiations restarted with the assistance of the United Nations, preferably under United Nations sponsorship and supervision.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to talk about our Governor-General. I do not want to talk about him in the same terms I publicly spoke about earlier today. The Governor-General and his office, as indeed all Australians would be aware because of the extensive media coverage, have been under some pretty severe attacks over the last week or so. It started with an article in the Daily Telegraph Mirror which commented upon the annual report of the Governor-General's office, which was presented in this place some time last week. Some of the headlines rang: `Hayden on the mat', `Words returned to haunt Hayden', `Pressure on Hayden to explain $10 million bill', `Why is it time to query the bill?', and `Hayden reboosts his New York workload'.

PARA.TAB: Some of the criticisms made, I believe, were quite legit. I am one of the people who have been critical in the past of some of what I consider to be the extravagances of the office. You would recall, Mr President, that I raised in the Labor Party caucus the cost of the trip to Gallipoli earlier this year. Some explanation has been offered on that. The current comment is going over the top and could be described as a pretty low attack on a very prominent individual and holder of a very high office in this country.

I refer in particular to the Telegraph Mirror of last Saturday, 21 October, in which the columnist Marcus Casey, under the heading `Bill and Dallas relax into holiday', had a go at the Governor-General and his wife whilst they were on holidays. I contend in this place and will contend publicly that whatever any public figure does when that public figure is on holidays is that individual's own business. If they choose to go off to Banff in Canada and have a relaxing holiday and stay at hotels reported to cost 1,500 bucks a night, that is their business; it is nobody else's business. If my wife and I choose to do that—we certainly wouldn't do it, although Jackie might encourage me—it is nobody else's business. If we wanted to engage in drinking red wine at what I consider to be an exorbitant cost, I do not believe that is the business of anybody in the Australian media or the Australian public, for that matter. It is not their business if that individual is on holiday.

I would defend the Governor-General's right to move to Vancouver, as was reported in the same paper on Monday of this week. He is reported to have stayed at a hotel in Vancouver costing $1,350 per night. The Governor-General, Mr Hayden, is reported to have said that he got that hotel for $800 a night. Good on him. If it saves him a quid, I am all for that too. I reiterate: it is nobody else's business what he does when he is on holiday.
The commentators who have jumped on the bandwagon and have blown this issue up ought to be condemned for doing that. Some of them have gone overboard.

I will make one comment in regard to Mr Hayden's defence, which I heard on radio. He said it would have been inappropriate for him, while he was travelling overseas, to carry his own bags. I wholeheartedly agree with the Governor-General's comment that he should not have to do that. He should not, when he is leaving an aircraft and being greeted officially in another country, have his hands encumbered by baggage so that the host cannot properly greet him.

I draw the line and say there does not need to be a private aircraft to avoid that occurring. Like other members of this parliament, I have travelled on official delegations. In fact, I led one. When I had to leave the aircraft to be officially greeted, others in the party took care of the hand baggage. On one occasion, all members of the delegation had their hands free to be greeted.

I make the point that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), whenever it is appropriate, travels on commercial aircraft. Earlier this year when he went to Japan, a very important trading partner of ours, he travelled commercially. He did not need to haul out either the small RAAF aircraft or the larger one.

I heard with great delight yesterday that the Queen, in her forthcoming visit to New Zealand, is going to acquiesce with the wishes of the New Zealand government and save them close on $1 million by travelling on a commercial aircraft to New Zealand. It can be done if the will is there. The Queen is certainly proving that. The Prime Minister has proved it.

The Governor-General, in the short time that he has left in that office prior to retirement, if he is to travel overseas any more, could practise that if it is appropriate. It may not be appropriate in all instances. It may be that there is a need to use a RAAF plane to get into inaccessible places on the way.

Some of the comments that have been made have been very unfortunate and damaging not only to the individual who has served Australia very well over the years but also to the high office that he holds. Some people have sought to damage what might be a presidential position at some time in the future by their comments on this occasion. I hope that in the future the analysis that takes place on matters like the cost of overseas travel is a little better researched than what we have seen in the last week or so in our media.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the thrust of Senator McKiernan's comments about the Governor-General. I do so, having been one who did not support his initial appointment. I say that quite clearly. However, I believe his performance in that job and that of Dallas, his wife, have been outstanding. He has performed his duties with dignity and with the common touch that is alleged in some of those articles he has abandoned.

PARA.TAB: I have not discovered any evidence to support the view that Bill Hayden has been anything other than a decent Australian, doing a good job in his role, which is, quite frankly, a fairly delicate one in view of the present debate about the role of the head of state.

I think he was quite unfairly criticised over the Gallipoli issue, in terms of whether or not he should have used the aircraft that is there—it is the government aircraft; it is the 707 that is being maintained by the government; and if it is not being used it is sitting on an airstrip. Sure, there are costs involved in running it. I thought it was appropriate that an effective head of state, going to a whole range of locations as he was on that trip, was quite properly advised to take the VIP fleet's 707.

He was unfairly criticised for the muck-up in the arrangements at Gallipoli. It was not his fault that, because the President of Turkey was there at a time when there were threats on his life, security was so tight that unfortunate mistakes were made which delayed two important ceremonies. That was unfortunate. It was grossly improper to blame the Governor-General for what happened.

I have to declare an interest in this. I have enjoyed the hospitality of the Governor-General at Government House. There is genuinely a much more egalitarian approach adopted by Mr Hayden and Dallas Hayden at Government House than there may have been in the past. There is still a requirement for a level of dignity to be maintained. I have no problem whatsoever with the manner in which he has undertaken his duties. I commend him for it. I regret that there was this kind of publicity towards the end of what has been a very successful term as Governor-General in difficult circumstances.

However, that is not what I want to talk about tonight. I am glad I had the opportunity of following Senator McKiernan. I want to talk about a report in the Australian about a company. The report states:
The Australian Federal Police has launched an investigation into a suspected attempt to defraud the Government's overseas aid agency, AusAID, of up to $250,000.
An AFP spokeswoman yesterday confirmed the Government had asked the AFP to investigate an Australian company in relation to the matter.
AusAID asked the AFP to investigate the matter last month after the company billed AusAID for allegedly false expenses of up to $250,000.
The company told AusAID it spent the money to establish a research and training centre in Indonesia as part of a 1994 agreement with AusAID.
However, AusAID referred the company's claim to its auditor in May after the majority of the claimed project costs could not be substantiated.
Further investigation by AusAID's auditor revealed that software claimed to have been supplied to the company by another Australian company was never supplied.

Investigations by AusAID officers in Indonesia also revealed that three organisations named by the company as being suppliers or associated with the project had neither supplied goods nor had any association with the project.
In view of the serious deficiencies revealed in the audit, AusAID last month requested that the AFP investigate the matter.
An AFP team is expected to travel to Indonesia soon to pursue its inquiries.
A spokesman for the Minister for Development, Co-operation, Mr Bilney, yesterday declined to comment on the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason that is of some concern to me is that I understand the company is the Indonesia-Australia Scientific Consortium and that it is effectively owned by a Mr Laurens Fluitman. The reason that causes me concern is that I raised in, I think, August of last year—well over a year ago—the extraordinary contract that Mr Fluitman had with the Department of Defence, which has now been referred to the Australian Federal Police, as the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) indicated in estimates hearings earlier this year.

PARA.TAB: There are several things that concern me about this. Firstly, I can find no evidence of any contract or any arrangements with the Indonesia-Australia Scientific Consortium in the latest report of AusAID, Business participation in AusAID's aid programs 1994-95, which lists not simply those projects in the current financial year, but more recent ones as well. I can see no indication of this contract which has been referred to the police.

I also am concerned that Mr Fluitman had also, I understood, put in an application relating to the Development Import Finance Facility-Export Finance and Insurance Corporation mixed credit scheme. I do not know to what extent this application has been rejected or what state it is in.

My concern stems from the fact that the matters I raised about Mr Fluitman were on the public record as of August last year. I am just wondering whether there is any effective mechanism by which one Australian agency which is concerned about various matters fully advises other Australian agencies of that concern. For example, I am aware of the fact, because I read it in the newspaper, that the Department of Defence ignored warnings by the Australian Secret Intelligence Service not to pay Mr Fluitman's company the money involved in its contract to obtain sensitive information about Indonesia's defence industry. Once again it is the Australian newspaper which has taken a great interest in these matters—and quite properly. The Australian newspaper says:

The ASIS warning, contained in secret cables sent from Jakarta in 1993, raises further questions about why the department went ahead with the deal, which is the subject of an investigation by the Australian Federal Police.

SPEECH.PARA: I should interpose now that I do hope that the restructuring involved in the Australian Federal Police is not limiting or inhibiting in any way the police inquiries into the matters I raised in August of last year.

PARA.TAB: I was advised by the minister and by the department on 23 June 1995 at Senate estimate hearings that the AFP commenced their investigations on 11 May this year into matters that the Inspector-General of Defence referred to the Federal Police in accordance with standing arrangements under a memorandum of agreement and that they were potentially criminal matters. I do hope that more notice is taken by government agencies of things like ASIS reports saying, `Don't do it'. I found it extraordinary that the Department of Defence, having been told it was inappropriate and unnecessary to pay a private company to do the work, continued to do so.

This Mr Fluitman, by the way, recently denied in a letter to the Australian that he and his company had done anything wrong. He attacked me for revealing the facts about his company and said that he had not been interviewed by the police, which I believe is not right. (Time expired)

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Defence Force: Capability and Preparedness

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 18 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the Australian Defence Force (ADF) have systems in place which enable it to measure the delivery of overall capability; if so, could a description of the methodology involved be provided.
(2) Can an assurance be given that the ADF can move from its current unit manning levels to their wartime approved strengths within the assigned readiness notices.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. The Australian Defence Force (ADF) does have systems in place which enable it to measure the delivery of overall capability.
Military Capability is measured against two discrete levels. These are:

Operational Level of Capability. A force element is at operational level of capability when it has the necessary resources and is sufficiently trained to perform the operational role and tasks specified in the Chief of the Defence Force's Preparedness Directive (CPD).
Minimum Level of Capability. A force element is at its minimum level of capability when it can achieve the operational level of capability within readiness notice, as specified in the CPD.

Military capability is the sum of the ADF's force structure and its preparedness. These are influenced by strategic circumstances, defence policy, operational priorities, and financial guidance. Force structure comprises manpower, equipment and facilities. Preparedness is the sum of readiness and sustainability.

Readiness relates to the ability of a force element to conduct designated operational roles and tasks within required timeframes (called readiness notice). The readiness component of preparedness can be defined in terms of the following:
Equipment—the availability of all items of equipment directly related to a capability.

Personnel—the requirement to man a force element at its minimum level of capability, and to provide those additional personnel needed to bring that force element to its operational level of capability within readiness notice.

Collective Training—the collective training to meet the designated minimum level of capability, and the work-up training it will need to reach the operational level of capability. Sustainability is the capacity to support forces from the time they reach their operational level of capability and are deployed or committed to operations, and until they have completed their assigned tasks.

Force structure adjustment is mainly undertaken through the force development process. The force development process aims to ensure that the Defence Organisation has the best balance of appropriate capabilities within the framework of the Government's strategic and financial guidance. The force development process consists of the following major steps.
Each key defence role, identified in strategic guidance, is analysed to derive from it the tasks that might have to be undertaken.
Capability-to-task analyses are conducted in order to determine the extent to which the current and planned force structure can and will continue to be able to carry out the tasks.
Analysis of options is undertaken to overcome deficiencies in the ability to undertake tasks. This includes concurrent analysis of personnel and operating cost implications.
Preferred options are developed into major capability proposals and submitted to Government for approval.
Approved proposals are incorporated into planning and resource allocation processes.
The current Chief of the Defence Force's Preparedness Directive (CPD) is an interim measure which indicates the preparedness objectives for the ADF.

Descriptions of the operational level of capability and minimum level of capability for force elements are developed by Service Chiefs of Staff, in conjunction with the Joint Commanders, using guidance given in the CPD. These judgements guide the assessment of whether preparedness objectives can be met.
The Biannual Preparedness Report outlines the state of preparedness of forces. Areas addressed in this report include shortcomings and the means of addressing them, as well as sustainability.

The CPD which is under development will detail tasks and preparedness objectives related to the strategic level plan for the defence of Australia and other national tasks for the force-in-being. Service Preparedness Directives will provide the detailed preparedness objectives for force elements.

(2) Yes. In most instances the ADF can move from its current unit manning levels to their wartime approved strengths within the assigned readiness notice. This is outlined in the following statements on each Service.

The RAN does not have `wartime' complements of ships and shore establishments. The complement of each Navy unit is structured to meet both peacetime and contingency tasks. Adjustments can be made to the complement and posted strength of individual units depending upon operational requirements. The Navy has the manpower to reach its operational level of capability within assigned readiness notices.
The operations and exercises conducted during 1994-95 demonstrated that generally, Regular Army forces are able to move to wartime approved strengths within assigned readiness notices.

Substantial recruitment is required to raise the current capacity of Army Reserve units, and the Reserve component of some composite units, to manning levels that would allow them to reach wartime approved strengths within the assigned readiness notice.

Air Force does not have designated `wartime' establishments for its units. It has a manpower structure comprising the minimum uniformed workforce required to meet and sustain the level of operational capability defined for short-warning conflict.

Except for a limited number of certain employment categories, such as some air crew and air traffic controllers, Air Force has the manpower to reach its operational level of capability within assigned readiness notices.
